PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
In this session of Parliament the proposed Bill of Rights will come before the Senate to be debated.
We, the undersigned, would like to voice our protest at the proposed Bill.

1. Because of the haste and secrecy with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives despite the fact that it will adversely affect areas of immense importance to liberty and freedom and is contrary to the spirit of the Australian Constitution.

2. The Bill is based upon the United Nations International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights which has been rejected both by the United States of America and Great Britain but accepted by the Warsaw Pact countries. We therefore believe there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many of whom do not practice the principles that they have covenanted to uphold.

3. Because our Australian Constitution states that `whereas we the people' give you the government these rights, the Constitution limits the right and power of government. The proposed Bill of Rights reverses this totally and states that `we the government, give you the people these rights'. This totally reverses the nature of government in this country.
4. Our rights and the principles of freedom are now protected by current legislation, Common law and the present Constitution.
5. Because it transfers the power of interpretation of legislation from the Parliament of Australia (the democratically elected institution) to the Courts (unelected body of people).

6. Because the Bill of Rights will be administrated by the Human Rights Commission which is an unelected body of people with powers which are outside and not subject to the normal processes of law-no appeal, closed hearings, no legal representation.

7. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights and just as inevitably the centralised control, by government, on human behaviour.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights in any shape or form being introduced in Australia.
Yours humbly

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, who would be aware of the developing crisis in the rental accommodation market, borne out by statistics which show a decline in the vacancy rate in State capital cities between November last year and January this year. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE USE AND EFFECTS OF CHEMICAL AGENTS ON AUSTRALIAN PERSONNEL IN VIETNAM

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs seen yesterday's Press reports claiming that two Swedish experts have written to the Governor-General alleging that the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam report misinterpreted and lied about the evidence they gave the Commission?

—Yes, I have seen the media speculation in the Press reports to which Senator McKiernan refers. Members of the media spoke to me on quite a number of occasions on the weekend seeking comment on the matters raised. All I can say at this stage is that I have asked the Secretary of my Department to give me an urgent report on the grave allegations that have been made by scientific persons and also on the fact, I understand, that a scientific person has written to the Governor-General making certain statements and allegations about the Royal Commissioner's report. —I draw the attention of the Minister for Education to reports that more than 33,000 people, including 477 working apprentices, have been turned away from technical and further education courses this year in New South Wales. I ask the Minister: Is she prepared to continue to allow such numbers to be turned away from TAFE courses, especially working apprentices who may well lose their apprenticeships if they do not get admitted to a TAFE course, or will her Government take positive action now to help to make sure that places are available for these apprentices and those requiring technical and further education? I ask the Minister further: Is the turning away of 477 working apprentices from TAFE another indication of the failure of the Priority One scheme to deliver what is needed for youth? Are the Government and the Minister prepared to tolerate a situation in which, due to the indifference or incompetence of the Labor Government in New South Wales, young Australians are not getting the chance to improve themselves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen no properly documented account supporting Senator Baume's claims about the numbers of young people who cannot get into TAFE courses, and in particular the number of apprentices in training who cannot get TAFE places. However, I am aware that there is likely to be a shortfall this year, as there has been in the past and as there will be in other years. However, that shortfall ought to be much less than it has been in previous years because one of the consequences for tertiary education of last year's Budget was the funding of an extra 15,000 TAFE places throughout Australia. I am not quite sure what proportion of those would have gone to New South Wales but I am sure a significant proportion would have done so. The situation is certainly much better than it has been but I expect that, when all the tertiary entrants' places have been allocated, there will be a shortfall. I hope that the shortfall will be less than it was last year. In response to Senator Baume's question, I can say that it is a matter of concern that there will be a shortfall.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Baume will be very well aware, in the TAFE sector the Commonwealth's contribution is about 30 per cent of the total and that of the States about 70 per cent. Most of the Commonwealth's contribution to TAFE under present arrangements is through the capital program which has been greatly expanded over recent years. I hope that that expansion will continue. It is also the case that some TAFE facilities are under-utilised because the recurrent funding is not adequate to utilise fully those facilities. This is a matter of concern to us and it is something that we will discuss with State governments in the near future. Senator Baume will be aware that the Commonwealth, through the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, has initiated a review of the Commonwealth's role in TAFE. As a result of that review, we will expect more co-operation with the States so that the funds that we make available through the capital program can be better utilised by an increased effort by the States in their recurrent contributions.

But it is certainly not the case that we regard unmet demand in TAFE as any sort of sign that Priority One is not working. Were it not for Priority One-were it not, for example, for the great increase in places in higher education and for the increased education allowances that enable children from less affluent families to study-we would see a much worse situation. We are confident that Priority One is working, particularly insofar as the education element is concerned. Participation rates in upper secondary schools are up in all parts of Australia, including New South Wales. That is partly because we have targeted those groups for greatly increased allowances under the secondary allowances scheme. There are many more places in universities and colleges of advanced education and this relieves the pressure on TAFE. As I have said, we have committed ourselves to an extra 15,000 places over the triennium. There is no doubt that we are making inroads into the unmet demand in those areas and we will continue to do so. With regard to the specific numbers cited in Senator Baume's question, I will ask the Tertiary Education Commission to comment on the accuracy of those claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the Government's program for the International Year of Peace. Has the Minister given consideration to a national `Australia for peace' campaign in which more Australians are encouraged to donate to or to sponsor a needy family in a third world nation? Does the Minister agree that such a project will enable people to feel that they have actually contributed to world peace as part of the Government's Year of Peace program? Will the Minister consider giving a public reassurance that donations or sponsorships through inter- national relief groups will in fact be spent on the people for whom they are given?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very interesting suggestion from Senator Elstob. No specific consideration has been given to a national Australia for peace campaign of the kind he has suggested but I shall certainly draw the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the proposal. The Government acknowledges that many Australians are already assisting needy families in Third World nations through various Australian and international relief groups and we do welcome the contribution that this makes to peace in the broadest sense of that term.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course we are undertaking a national communications campaign to raise public awareness of the many different dimensions of the International Year of Peace. We believe that this effort will be of assistance to the many existing campaigns being run by Australian and inter- national relief groups.

Finally, the Government respects the autonomy of the relief groups, which generally have a sound reputation. However, it does not become involved in the internal workings of these organisations and has no authority to monitor the expenditure of privately raised funds.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BROKEN HILL PROPRIETARY CO. LTD: TAKEOVER BID

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, relates to the Holmes a Court bid to control the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I ask: Firstly, has the Government sought any assurances from Mr Holmes a Court on this matter; secondly, if so, what is the nature of the assurances sought and what specific undertakings were given; and thirdly, how is it possible for such assurances to be guaranteed in a public company responsible to the decisions of its Board and its shareholders, and to changes of directors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes, the Government has sought assurances from Mr Holmes a Court. The assurances which were sought, while fairly wide reaching, were essentially directed to those areas in respect of which the Commonwealth Government has a particular interest on behalf of taxpayers in the affairs or takeover of BHP. The first of those issues to which we particularly directed attention was the future of the steel industry in respect of which the Government has substantial commitments arising from the steel industry plan. The second area in which we sought assurances related particularly to protection of Commonwealth revenue.

ANSWER.PARA: I was next asked whether I will publicise the nature of those assurances. The answer to that question is: Not at the present time. Assurances have been given not only orally but in writing by both BHP and Mr Holmes a Court. We sought assurances from both of them. It is not appropriate for us to disclose the details of those assurances while an action is currently proceeding in the Supreme Court of Victoria dealing with very similar matters. I must say that the parties sought some indulgence from the Government on that question which I am sure Senator Sir John Carrick would fully understand.

The next part of the question was: How is it possible for a public company like BHP to make sure that the assurances given will be met? That is a very complex question to answer, but let me say that all the anxiety about this takeover assumes that Mr Holmes a Court would, to put it mildly, be in an immensely influential position in the affairs of BHP if his bid succeeded. It is in dealing with that assumption that one has to seek assurances in the manner in which the Government did.

I conclude by saying that in respect of assurances of that sort, I doubt whether the fact that they are given to a particular individual or a particular tribunal of inquiry or to the Government makes very much difference in respect of the last part of the question. Once power or influence in a public company of that kind resides in a particular set of hands, either singular or plural, the test of whether those assurances are carried out remains the public credibility of the person or persons who gave the assurances.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question of the Minister. Do I take it that when the matter is concluded before the Supreme Court the Government will make those undertakings public? Secondly, am I to understand that what in fact is said by the Minister as to the enforceability of the assurances is that virtually there is no enforceable way of guaranteeing the undertakings given? If so, why ask for the assurances at all?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that I had answered the last part of the question already. The question arises from a lot of shared anxiety and concern in some quarters of the community about the present management of BHP and in other quarters of the community about the possible management of BHP under a new regime which might result from a successful takeover bid by Mr Holmes a Court. The answer to that question is that it is in respect of those sorts of concerns that assurances were sought.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick also asked me whether the Government will publish those undertakings given in writing on completion of the Supreme Court case. I think the best way I can answer that is to say that it is the Government's intention to do so, subject to the deletion of matters which either of the parties regard as commercial in confidence, and I think that before we publish that material we would, again, have to consult the parties, although they understand that it is our intention to do so in due course. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Now that the Government's decision to reduce the price of oil has taken effect at the petrol pump, is the Minister satisfied that the reduction in price per barrel has been fully passed on to the Australian motorist? Will the Government be enlisting the support of relevant State government authorities to monitor price changes to make sure that there is a real and enduring cut? Can the Government identify for consumers those products and services which should fall in price because of the oil price cut to make sure that the downstream effect is properly reflected in the consumer price index and in consumers' pockets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prices Surveillance Authority, of course, sets the maximum wholesale price for petroleum products for each capital city. These maximum wholesale prices were reduced on Friday, by 5.77c per litre for motor spirit, producing the result that in Sydney the maximum wholesale price is now 47.55c per litre, in Melbourne 48.34c, in Brisbane 43.82c, Perth 45.99c, Adelaide 46.64c, and Hobart 47.15c. Retail prices are set by the refining companies in the first instance, then by distributors and agents; a combination of the two produces the final result. The normal retail margin is somewhere between 1c and 5c, depending on gallonage through the particular site, and, in addition to that, of course, one has to take into account the transport costs, which are much greater for country and provincial areas than they are in the capital cities.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not the case that any of these matters are now the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government or any of its agencies, particularly the Prices Surveillance Authority, to monitor, but I think that I can make some comments about the retail price situation as follows in terms of when the price drops I have mentioned are likely to come into effect. The first point would be that in areas in which retailers were paying the maximum or near the maximum wholesale price, consumers could expect the price of petrol to fall immediately by between 5c and 6c per litre, and most country areas and those cities in which there has been no significant discounting in the past clearly fall into that category. The second point I would make is that prices could be expected to fall fastest in areas where competition is high, in the major cities, and slower in country areas, where retailers will undoubtedly try to retrieve some of their costs of existing stocks; but within 10 days of the announcement, all consumers should see some drop in the price of oil. Certainly they should be asking their retailers why there has been no drop if some price effect has not shown up by the end of this week or early next week.

The final point I would make about all this is that in areas in which discounting has been prevalent-and that has certainly been in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide in recent times-some consumers may not see a 5c or 6c per litre fall. There has been some evidence that discounting in the places I have mentioned has been much less in the last fortnight, as refiners and, to a much lesser extent, retailers have sought to scramble to recover some of their stock loss. So, to the extent that discounting has been less in the last two or three weeks, then the price effect of the wholesale reduction I have mentioned should be greater. I should make the point that the existence of discounting in the past is evidence that the industry competes fiercely for market shares, and one result of that is likely to be competition to force the retail price down the full 5c or 6c per litre, particularly in areas where there has been that pattern of discounting.

As to the implications for prices in the shops, again that is not a matter which the Commonwealth Government has any capacity or constitutional power to monitor. It is unlikely that retailers of consumer goods will actually drop the price of their commodities or be under pressure to do so unless the commodities in question have a very high energy input or very high transport costs associated with them. I simply express the hope on the part of the Government that those shops and supermarkets in the past which have put up their prices because of alleged increased transportation costs will follow the logic of that position under consumer pressure and will now bring down the prices in question.

The effect of the drop of fuel prices is more likely to flow through into consumer prices generally as the reduction in the consumer price index from the reduction in fuel prices takes effect. I remind the Senate, finally, that that reduction is expected to be of the order of half a per cent in the first instance, with second round indirect effects of at least another half a per cent and probably, in the longer run, substantially more than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether his attention has been drawn to reports about the behaviour of certain members of the Royal Australian Air Force at the Williamtown base in New South Wales in which, in what was alleged to be a series of instructions to `toughen the moral fibre' of the Royal Australian Air Force personnel concerned, they were required to maltreat kittens, in the first instance by attempting to pull their claws out with their teeth and, if that failed, using pliers; secondly, to stamp on the heads of a number of kittens; thirdly, to break the kittens' legs with pliers; and fourthly, to put them in clothes dryer machines, turn them on full, and in effect cook the animals. —I have heard the reports to which Senator Puplick refers and, I imagine in common with every other Australian, have been appalled by what I have heard. I have no brief on the matter at this stage because the truth of the matter is still being sorted out. No doubt it will be possible to say something on the matter quite soon when the Department of Defence finds out what has happened and can brief the Minister and me accordingly. I simply say that I have an absolute incomprehension, combined with disgust, that such things could possibly have occurred-if, indeed, they did occur. I do not think it is appropriate for anyone to jump to conclusions until the facts of the matter are know; but if it should prove to be the case that behaviour of that kind occurred, I do not think there would be anyone in this Government or any part of the country who would resist the course of action which Senator Puplick obviously thinks would be appropriate.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy to statements made by Sheikh Yamani about oil prices dropping to $US8 a barrel. Will the Minister state what impact such a development could have for Australian oil if Australia followed this price for its crude? Will the Minister also state what will happen to the ratio mix of imported to locally produced oil and whether a development along these lines will adversely affect this mix in favour of imported oils?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that Sheikh Yamani has suggested that prices might go even lower than they are at the moment-perhaps, as Senator Foreman said, to $US8 a barrel or less. No doubt Sheikh Yamani was making that comment in the context of the current meeting of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries in a desire to put the squeeze on his mavericks, as well as to send appropriate signals to North Sea and other non-OPEC producers. It is certainly possible that prices could fall that low in the short run, but I do not think that anyone thinks that the market forces would operate in such a way as to allow prices to stay at that low level indefinitely. At that price level the pressures on producers around the world-the Gulf states excepted-would be absolutely enormous and we could expect consequential production cuts to bring prices up to more acceptable levels.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian producers will not be immune to these pressures and Australia can expect to see some reduction in production levels flowing from the present price situation. It is also the case that producers and governments will suffer revenue losses through lower prices for as long as they persist. If extremely low prices do persist for some time we could expect to see these production cuts and, more importantly, cuts in exploration flowing from reduced cash flow to producers leading to a decline in Australian self-sufficiency, combined with the corresponding increase in petroleum imports. That is one of the reasons why I and the Government have constantly reiterated that, despite some of the superficial attractions of lower oil prices, in the longer run anything much less than around $US20 a barrel as the prevailing world price is not in the interests of this country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

ANSWER.PARA: On the more general question of time lost through industrial disputes, for Australia as a whole the number of days lost through disputes in the year ending November 1985 was less than one-third of the number of days lost in 1979 and 1981. —Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women aware that the Queensland, Tasmanian and Northern Territory governments have failed to implement women's policy through administrative and advisory structures as adopted in all other States for many years? In fact, Queensland seems to have more policies directed towards animals than women. How can the Federal Government's national agenda campaign assist these women whose governments continue to neglect women's needs in education, employment, health, housing, welfare and legal status?

—It is certainly true that because of the negligence of those non-Labor governments instanced in Senator Reynolds's question women in those States are not benefiting as much from the improved policies for women as many other women throughout Australia. For example, in the State of Queensland the only legislation that assists women who are discriminated against is the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act, but I am pleased to say that that Act is operative in Queensland and it is giving some assistance to women, although women who are employed, for example, by the Queensland State Government have no protection at all because it is necessary for the State Government to legislate in that area. Similarly, although we have established in Brisbane a women's information service to give better information to the women of Queensland about their entitlements under various Commonwealth programs, it is true to say that they are very much at a disadvantage compared with women in the Labor States. However, in order to provide further opportunities for Queensland women and women in the non-Labor States to have an input into Commonwealth Government policy we are planning a series of consultations throughout those States so that those women can participate in the formation of the national agenda for women, which will be a program for improving the status of women from now until the year 2000. It is without doubt the most ambitious program of consultations that any government has undertaken. I think it will establish very clear directions for our Government on the needs of Australian women as identified and articulated by them. We are determined that Queensland women and women in the other non-Labor States will not be excluded from this but that a high priority will be given to organising consultations with them and taking account of their views. One major consultation for women of the west in Queensland has already taken place in Mount Isa and I understand that it was extremely well attended. We are not discriminatory in these matters; we are genuinely seeking the views of Australian women, who may participate in this exercise along with all other women. In answer to Senator Reynolds's question, I believe that the program of national consultations for the national agenda for the year 2000 will be a most welcome opportunity for Queensland women otherwise having enormous difficulties in making their voices heard to put items of concern to them on the national agenda.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Art is essential to the welfare of the community. A considerable amount of time is spent in the Parliament in economic debate. There is a perception that, if the economic mechanism is correctly structured and maintained, society will prosper and be happy. Clearly, this is not so. In the end it is the spirit, the aspirations and the determination of a community that count. Those elements are the product of culture, not of economics. A whole mathematics of economics can be created. I wish to make a few comments on this report of the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board because of the organisation's significance and importance. It is now 10 years since the organisation was formed and 20 years since it was first discussed. The Anglo-Australian Telescope Agreement was signed in 1971 and the unit itself, a 3.9 metre telescope, was built at a cost of about $16m. The operation has been and still is funded jointly by Australia and the United Kingdom and at present costs each country about $1.8m a year to operate. The telescope is located at Siding Springs, which, until the last couple of months, may not have been heard of by many people. Siding Springs has a great advantage in that it is so located as to be virtually free of what the report terms light pollution. It is interesting to note that the report comments about this, saying:

. . . the Board and the Australian National University are very pleased that an environmental study will be undertaken by the New South Wales Government to consider long term measures for protecting the very dark sky conditions at Siding Spring Observatory. It is important that protection measures be introduced before the problem of light pollution becomes a serious threat to the site.

For the operation of a telescope such as this, which, of course, works primarily at night, it is a very important matter. The future of the telescope operation has been under some discussion. Astronomy, of course, is very much pure science and, as such, not many people involved in the monetarist situations which seem to pervade the world at present, in both Australia and the United Kingdom in this case, really understand the value and virtue of the science of astronomy and in turn, of course, the telescope. It looks to many people as though it is just an expense item. The Siding Springs organisation has done a lot of work in connection with the comet. I think it is in that regard that so many people have suddenly heard of this place called Siding Springs. The work that has been done there has been of a very high standard. It is an excellent operation and something of which we in Australia can be very proud, because it is producing results that are very useful all over the world. SPEECH.PARA: Australia is very vulnerable, in defence and trade, to the loss of top scientists and of technical experts. SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I take this opportunity to make a few remarks on the annual report of the Arbitration Inspectorate because of the importance of the report and the work behind it. The report details the work of the Arbitration Inspectorate in the financial year 1984-85 and lists areas of concern such as the number of award investigations carried out by the Inspectorate. At the heart of the report is the maintenance of Federal awards. At present, 1,676 awards are in force federally and, of an estimated 5.6 million wage and salary earners, some two million are presently covered by Federal awards. In my State of South Australia the percentage of wage and salary earners covered by Federal awards is 33.9 per cent, or slightly more than one-third. This percentage is smaller than the percentage of State awards, which for 1984-85 was 52.8 per cent of the work force. Yet the number of South Australians covered under Federal awards was significant and appeared to have been growing in 1984-85. Some 224 new Federal awards were sought. The vital task of the Inspectorate is to scrutinise the awards closely. Its job is to ascertain whether awards are maintained in all the relevant areas and to investigate complaints relating to employer non-compliance.

The Opposition, of course, has a problem in this area of awards, according to its public pro- nouncements. It believes in flexibility-the flexibility to dissolve awards or for opting out so that legitimate wage justice can be white-anted. Australians from all walks of life and over many years have seen the necessity to have awards in place. In this sense a fair day's work results in a fair day's pay. Workers under the arbitrated award system receive commonality of pay and conditions and the strength and popularity of the arbitration system have resulted from general public acceptance and perception of the basic fairness of industrial awards.

The Inspectorate was established in 1928 to ensure compliance with awards. The arbitration system goes back to 1904, or three years after Federation. Since this time the Inspectorate has been the instrument to enforce legitimate award entitlements for workers. In 1984-85 some 24,236 breaches of awards were reported, as compared with 24,021 cases in 1983-84. The enforcement of awards resulted in $3,721,578 being paid to employees and this shows an increase of over $209,275 over the previous year.

The report, I am pleased to say, shows that the Inspectorate has obviously established a good working relationship with employers and employees alike. The overwhelming number of award violations by employers was rectified voluntarily. In fact, in 1984-85 3,830 employers agreed to rectify the matter before other machinery came into force. The machinery to enforce legitimate awards is and has been in place for many years. It is pleasing to note, though, that this machinery is becoming more effective. In 1984-85 17 employers were referred for prosecution and all prosecutions were upheld by the court. The actions involved some 123 breaches of awards. In the previous year the record was still a sound one but not quite as complete with 91 out of 94 breaches being legally rectified.

One of the major functions of the Inspectorate is the provision of information. Many inquiries are made of the Inspectorate, of which the majority indicate no breaches of awards. I note in the report that in respect to award complaints and inquiries, 61 per cent of formal complaints were upheld in 1984-85, as opposed to 54 per cent in 1983-84. It is my view that it is important to have a well oiled piece of machinery to enforce legitimate wage and salary awards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the previous debate on Article 2, a number of honourable senators referred to the American Bill of Rights and saw in it a useful model for an Australian Bill of a similar nature. The fact is that those who have done so, in my view, have little or no knowledge of American history. To draw attention to the American Bill of Rights and see virtue in it is to fail to understand, for example, that under that Bill of Rights for centuries the American negro was not regarded as a human being and was not allowed the right to marry. The whole persecution and ill-treatment of negroes, blacks, happened under the American Bill of Rights. There was no recourse.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred previously to two other matters. I referred to what people ought to know as the yellow dog contract which, under the Hoover regime, was an outrage. The contract was also called the iron clad contract. People who wanted jobs were forced to sign a contract saying that they would not join any association. This was under the Bill of Rights that is held up to us as a classic preservation. It gave no protection at all for blacks. We now see that it had no protection for those in the work force. I drew attention to another case. It was outstanding. From my memory, it happened in the early 1920s and was known as the Sacco and Vanzetti case. It concerned two illegal Italian aliens, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, who were charged with murder of a pay master. Their case drew on, without ordinary recourse to habeas corpus, over many years. They were ultimately executed. The strong belief prevailed that it was not the test of their guilt as murderers which resulted in the execution but the fact that they were alleged to be anarchists and therefore should be punished. Individuals' freedoms were absolutely denied in that time. The Sacco and Vanzetti case became a cause celebre throughout the United States of America and is in most of the text books of political science relating to that time, and to the Hoover period.

Those who understand the Roosevelt period of the New Deal could scarcely believe that there could be any protection in the Bill of Rights. I have reminded the Senate that President Roosevelt, who succeeded Hoover, had to change the whole of the Supreme Court Bench to get a new interpretation, so the yellow dog contract could be rejected. Those who understand the force of the irony of the situation know that he appointed as a chief justice, Mr Hugo Black, who turned out to be a member of the Ku Klux Klan. For those who admire the American Bill of Rights against that background I quote a very distinguished President of the United States of America, Woodrow Wilson. I quote his words about rights because they are fundamental. He said:
Liberty has never come from the government. Liberty has always come from the subjects of it. The history of liberty is the history of residence.

If Woodrow Wilson had believed that liberty came from the Bill of Rights why would he say that? He was the World War I President of the United States of America, who had behind him the whole of American history and the tremendous civil war in America. The fact is that, as President and knowing all those things, he said that liberty has never come from the government. That is the truth. Liberty has come from the community and is protected by the community. I do not criticise the United States of America. The 350 years of the history of the United States of America is the history of the emergence of freedom. But to go further, if people regard the American Bill of Rights as something that we should use as a model I simply say that under that Bill of Rights segregation occurred, not only prior to the civil war, not only before blacks had the right to citizenship, but also in world wars, when negroes were segregated in their battalions. There was a situation in which, although fighting racism, racism was entrenched.

Fundamentally, I rose to continue the point that must be made in any discussion of whether there ought to be a Bill or Rights. Rights are not entrenched by a document. Rights are entrenched when a community cherishes liberty and is willing to fight to defend that liberty. Lenin, who knew something about rights, said:
It is true that liberty is precious-so precious that it must be rationed.

Who better than Nikolai Lenin would have understood the rationing of liberty? Of course, that is exactly what has happened in the USSR, where when liberty is written down, it is rationed. Again, the whole basis of this matter must be to look at why we want this Bill. It is no use looking at written documents. It has been said in the debate that socialist countries, Iron Curtain countries, have written bills of rights-but they have not conveyed any rights. What is important is whether in the community, the parliamentary system, the judicial system and the evolution of common law the general social and cultural values of the people are so entrenched that governments will not encroach on or take away from people more and more liberty. One of the great defenders and philosophers of liberty Salvador de Madariaga, a Spanish philo- sopher, in recent decades said:
Liberty of thought means liberty to communicate one's thought.

That means the absolute freedom to communicate one's thoughts. This Bill of Rights quaintly says that we are guaranteed freedom of thought. I would not have thought that in any document that emerged in Australia it would be thought necessary to write the principle of freedom of thought. What kind of a community envisages that people are not free to think as they like? One ought to have the true freedom to understand that one may have to observe relative values, judgments and truths in one's walk in life alongside others. But one is allowed to look in the wider sphere, even in the more anarchic sphere of freedom, in one's mind. One should be able to fly free in one's mind. There is no need in the world to write those absolutely unnecessary words into the document. The more one looks at a situation, particularly in the history of America, the more one comes to understand that nothing in the journey protected the people of America under the Bill of Rights.

I remind the Senate that I commented very briefly upon the committee which was set up in the late 1960s by Lyndon Johnson to look into violence. The committee was asked to find out why violence and trouble had occurred amongst the blacks. The committee comprised eminent persons-members of Congress, heads of the police forces and others-and concluded that in fact Americans had created the situation by breaking up the tribal systems from Africa; by bringing people to America as slaves; by refusing even to let them establish the smallest unit of a tribe, a family, by denying them marriage; by urging them to breed so that they could get a capital gain; by separating them in the various plantations. All this took place under a Bill of Rights which was absolutely useless in that regard. Even after the Civil War, when a war had been fought to free the slaves and won by those from the north, the blacks were still under heavy penalty.

It has been stated that the laws passed in America during that time helped to free the blacks. Those laws did not protect the blacks in any way; it was attitudes of mind. I referred to a particular zoological garden that was closed down because the law said that it had to be shared. I remember when there was a particular part for blacks and a particular part for whites in the buses in America. The law said that this was no longer to be the case so the whites did not ride on those buses but arranged their own transport. Nothing by way of law brought freedoms to the blacks in America. What happened was that gradually, over a period of decades, the American conscience was alerted. Gradually the truth emerged of what had happened-a white race impinging upon the blacks with slavery and then serfdom. Gradually the conscience built up to do something and that is precisely what happened. But certainly nowhere in that journey did the American Bill of Rights protect the blacks. Nowhere in the journey did the American Bill of Rights protect all of the people of America during the Great Depression of the 1930s.

How was it that that Bill of Rights allowed the Supreme Court of America to declare as unconstitutional Roosevelt's National Labor Recovery Act? How was it that all that New Deal legislation-the Agricultural Adjustment Act, the NLRA and all those New Deal Acts-resisted by the Supreme Court and yet there was a Bill of Rights? They did not need to amend the Bill of Rights; they had to change their judiciary to get the National Labor Recovery Act and the New Deal legislation passed in America. So, fundamentally, do not let us use words simply to support an argument. There is no justification for saying that the American Bill of Rights has of itself ensured the freedom of the people of America. It certainly entrenched a series of things. The right to carry arms has been entrenched in the American Constitution. Whether that has been a good or a bad thing is for those to test. But, in the end, we come back to the simple question of what is liberty. George Bernard Shaw said:
Liberty means responsibility; that is why men dread it.

I conclude on this aspect by reminding the Senate that Woodrow Wilson, who knew the history of the Bill of Rights, had no reliance on government in the preservation of liberty and freedom. He saw liberty and freedom as a yeasting, a vital movement within the community itself and not something entrenched by words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are but 15 minutes back into this debate and already I feel a clammy, oppressive sense of deja vu. We have been here before and we have had this debate on the second reading. We have had a very substantial slab of this same debate under our earlier discussion of Article 2, and here we are having it again. Mr Chairman, I urge that, despite the ambit of Article 2 to which you drew our attention on a previous occasion, it might be helpful if we were to go on to some of the more specific matters in this Bill and abandon some of the more repetitive discussion that we now seem to be embarking on once again. With all the persistence of a rhetorically inclined terrier, we had Senator John Carrick come back to this issue of--
—Only because you raised it.

—I was responding to a previous argument, and it seems that I need to do so once more, albeit very briefly. Senator Sir John Carrick argued that a Bill of Rights did nothing to protect the rights of Americans in general or blacks in particular until the 1950s. There is a lot to be said for the truth of that assertion. I think he and I agree-I have tried before to point out the area of our agreement-that a Bill of Rights by itself will not do the job of the protection of rights. One does need a spirit of the times abroad in a country that is sensitive to human rights issues and willing to support the kinds of guarantees contained in a formal document. There is no such spirit of the times abroad in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or many other countries that have bills of rights, whether of a declaratory or purportedly enforceable kind. It is the case that that spirit was quite conspicuously lacking in the United States of America for the first century and a half of the operation of the Bill of Rights. A whole series of doctrines, substantive due processes and the like did operate, arguably in a way that was no help at all to liberty as well as, of course, being of no help to blacks in the context of the equal protection law.

SPEECH.PARA: But the point that I keep coming back to-it is a very important one-is that one can acknowledge all that and yet still argue very successfully for the utility of a Bill of Rights as an incentive for particular developments to take place faster, in perhaps different directions and with a greater effectiveness, than they otherwise would. In the 1950s it was very difficult to argue that the spirit of the times then existed for the kind of massive stride that was made by the United States Supreme Court in Brown v. Board of Education, the watershed case in 1954. The Supreme Court was ahead of the population then and it was the capacity of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and its predecessor organisations to use in a visionary way the terms of the Bill of Rights to wrench America out of the lethargy and apathy that had afflicted it in that area of enormous human rights damage being incurred to black American citizens. It was the Supreme Court that led the way. The Supreme Court for more than a generation has been leading the way in a number of human rights areas. It cannot be said that it is just limping along in the rear in the wake of developments that would have occurred anyway to the same extent and with the same effectiveness.

It is a long argument and we have obviously canvassed both dimensions of it. But I draw attention once again to the difference between necessary and sufficient conditions. Nobody argues that a Bill of Rights by itself is a sufficient condition for the long protection of liberty. But a Bill of Rights properly drafted, sensitively drafted, can make a good society better. It can make a just society more just if it is structured in such a way and reflects the spirit of the age and the country in such a way that it simply gives added leverage and added force to currents of opinion broadly evident in that community as a whole. That remains the rationale of a Bill of Rights for Australia. I do not seek to put it on any higher or more magical ground than that. I do not seek to contest the force of much of what has been said by Senator Sir John Carrick in his commentary on the United States situation. But I do think that the difference in perspective between us is really very important and bears repetition on this occasion, even though I had hoped that we would be able to get back to the substance of the Bill rather more swiftly than seems likely to be the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to make some comments on what Senator Sir John Carrick had to say about the deficiencies with regard to the United States Bill of Rights, and I do so in the context of the comments made in the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs Exposure Report: A Bill of Rights for Australia on whether or not Australia should have a Bill of Rights. As Senator Evans has quite rightly said, Senator Sir John Carrick is correct in his statement that the US Bill of Rights did not of itself protect the rights of Americans, either as a group or as sections of Americans. One of the reasons that it did not do that was that, as the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee pointed out, the American Bill of Rights is drafted in generally unqualified terms. Only a few rights are stated specifically and in limited terms in the American Bill of Rights and as a consequence the Bill and its contents are subject to interpretation by the courts. As most of us are aware, the American judicial system is a far more political one than the Australian judicial system. As the Committee reports:

SPEECH.PARA: But it places on the judiciary a heavy burden of determining through interpretation and implication how rights may be qualified.

The Committee regards this as unsatisfactory. It is also undesirable to have a text which, by making such limited reference to qualifications, implies that most rights and freedoms can be exercised even in totally irresponsible ways.

The other problem that lies in the United States Bill of Rights approach is that it is entrenched in America's Constitution and can be amended only by a fairly tortuous process. That means that, again as Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out, it is not always appropriate to the conditions of the times. He mentioned the rights to bear arms, which was certainly appropriate when it was inserted-it was put there for a very good reason-but it has caused immense problems in the twentieth century.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the courts have never interpreted that as a guarantee of the right to carry small arms and rifles, despite the NRA. That ought to be put on the record.
—Fair enough, but it is constantly waved about by various pressure groups in the American community.
—But it has no legal force in this context.

—Certainly; nevertheless, it is used to whip up some sort of frenzy about their rights to get the sort of public opinion that Senator Sir John Carrick was talking about as being appropriate to establishing what rights are. I imagine this is one of the reasons why the Committee did not recommend a change to the Constitution with regard to this Bill of Rights. It said that it recognised that most rights and freedoms cannot exist in absolute or unqualified terms in the manner in which they apply in the United States Bill. It is recognised that there would be occasions when some individuals' rights or freedoms would have to be qualified so as to protect other individuals' rights and freedoms or even so as to protect some general public interest. It gave some greater approval to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms than it gave to the United States Bill of Rights, but in the long run it considered that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if a Bill of Rights adapted to Australia's circumstances is contemplated it should be drafted in a way which vitalises Parliaments by keeping them aware of fundamental rights and freedoms and sensitive to the effect of their activities on such rights and freedoms and which requires elected Parliaments to take public responsibility for their adherence to or departure from any of the provisions of such a Bill of Rights.
So the onus is on the parliaments to ensure, as they should, that people's rights are protected.

There is a belief in the community that this is not necessary because our rights are already protected by everything from the Magna Carta through to common and statute law. The Committee's report ends that myth for all time by referring to a range of common or statute law provisions which the community generally believes exist and which in fact do not. These range from the principle of habeas corpus, which it deals with in paragraph 2.32, through to the fact that a recent South Australian Supreme Court decision determined that religious freedom does not exist in absolute terms, referring in a number of places to the Grace Bible Church v. Reedman case. It pointed out in paragraph 2.35 that in fact we do not have the right to privacy in this country as we believe we do, that we do not have under the Constitution an absolute right to vote, and that the absolute right to legal representation at a trial was overruled by the High Court of Australia decision in the McInnis case. It refers to that at some length in paragraph 2.27. Similarly, the right to own private property is limited under the Federal Constitution to the right to not have that property unjustly acquired, but certainly that does not extend to the States since no State constitution contains a similar clause. Interestingly, and rather ironically, the fact that this Bill itself does not extend to cover the States means that any amendment which does insert the right to own private property and not to have it unjustly acquired as a part of the Covenant will not achieve anything that is not already achieved by the Federal Constitution until and unless the Bill itself is extended to apply to the States.

So certainly most of us would agree with Senator Sir John Carrick that the United States Bill of Rights is a very poor peg on which to hang the Australian Bill of Rights and, quite rightly, the Government chose not to go in that direction but instead to follow more closely the route taken by Canada when it chose to introduce its Charter of Rights and Freedoms. In doing so it has enshrined in a legislative process for the first time some of those principles that people have mistakenly believed were held under common law-the right to religious freedom, the right to privacy, the right to legal representation, the right to vote, the right to freedom of thought and conscience, including the right to hold opinions without interference, and a number of others. I would have thought that, in a democracy at least, Senator Sir John Carrick and others would have held dearly to that particular right since it would be appalling if at any stage we lived in a country where people's right to hold opinions, their right to freedom of thought and conscience, was derogated from in any way at all.

The Government has attempted to avoid some of the worst deficiencies in the United States situation by adopting this method, by not attempting to enshrine such provisions in legislation, where change is extremely difficult, but to leave them in the hands of elected representatives by putting them in a Bill which can be adjusted as times change so that we do not run into the sort of situation that Senator Sir John Carrick raised where a right, such as the right to bear arms, which is appropriate at one time in a country's history, comes into play quite inappropriately at another period in that country's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does Article 2, the right of freedom existing under any other law, apply to State public servants? Does the Bill, in total, apply to any State public servants?
—I am sorry. Can you be more precise? What aspect are you suggesting is or is not, might or might not be, applicable to a public servant? I cannot quite work out what you are saying.
—I am just asking a general question. Does this Bill apply to any State public servant?

But there is no question of a State law authorising the behaviour of a State public servant pursuant to that law being overridden because the Bill is not applicable to the States in its present form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am forced to my feet by Senator Evans's outburst. The fact of the matter is that the Government, under the responsibility of the Attorney-General, has introduced this legislation. We are being given all sorts of advice about what it does and does not mean and about what it does and does not do. TALK.START.PARA: —Article 3 raises grave questions as to the constitutionality of the whole legislation. Indeed the Law Council of Australia had recommended that for a variety of reasons Article 3 (1) be deleted. To understand this it is necessary to point out that the Government has said that the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is modelled on the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, but in fact it wanders from that Covenant in many respects. The departure from the terms of the Covenant raises questions as to the constitutional validity of the Bill of Rights itself. The Covenant provides throughout its articles quite a number of qualifications; the Bill that is before the Committee does not recognise quite a number of them. As a result, in relation to Article 3 of the Australian Bill of Rights, the Law Council of Australia describes two hurdles which must be satisfied, in its words, if a limitation on a right or freedom set out in the Bill is to be permissible. I quote from the Law Council of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: By means of Article 3.2 the Australian Bill of Rights incorporates by reference the limitations and qualifications contained in the Covenant. This is not the most satisfactory method of dealing with the question, because it does not specify which of the relevant articles should be qualified, nor in what way they should be qualified. In the explanatory memorandum it is explained that these qualifications have not been reproduced because of the perceived need `to produce an inspirational charter of rights in a simple declaratory style'.
The Law Council goes on:
The Law Council does not support the use of a simple declaratory style if it would lead to uncertainty.
It goes on to say:

Further and more importantly, Article 3 (1) adds another hurdle which has no counterpart on the covenant. Apart from any constitutional question which might arise from the addition of Article 3 (1), Article 3 (1) creates a test for permissible limitation which is extraordinarily difficult to prove. A limitation will be permitted only if it `can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'. This criterion is extraordinarily uncertain. What is a democratic society? By what criterion does one judge whether a society is free and democratic? The burden of proving that the particular law is `demonstrably justified' suggests that it must be patently clear. Is it required to be so certain as to admit of no qualification?
That is the end of the quotation from the Law Council of Australia. If I may say so, that is a pretty persuasive argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is persuasive if you have no legal imagination whatsoever.

—The Minister will get his chance to reply. This is a body of law. It is true that it is the only one in step in the regiment. That is not unusual. This is a body which represents 20,000 lawyers. I know that a narcissus complex can override that, but I think it is worth considering that what the Law Council of Australia says is relevant to this may bear some relevance, even though we have the arrogance of expression already today from the Minister. I draw the Committee's attention to, and quote from, Article 3 (1). This article ought to be the haven for lawyers for generations to come. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The rights and freedoms set out in this Bill of Rights are subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.

Is not the Law Council of Australia right to ask what these words can mean-these declaratory and very imprecise words? What is `a free and democratic society'? How can one argue what that means? Canada could say that it is a free and democratic society; the United States of America would say so; Australia would, and the United Kingdom would, also-but all within their own boundaries would have different meanings and different nuances regarding freedoms. So, quite rightly, the Law Council of Australia says that so imprecise are these terms that the article ought to be looked at in terms of deletion. But the Law Council goes on to get to questions of the onus of proof. It says:

The addition of this second hurdle goes beyond the Covenant and may require a person seeking to reply on a limitation or qualification permitted by the Covenant to discharge this uncertain and perhaps shifting onus of proof. For example, laws of libel which qualify the freedom of opinion in speech protected by Articles 7 and 8 of the Australian Bill of Rights are recognised in Article 19 (3) of the Covenant. However, if the laws of libel are challenged as being contrary to Articles 7 and 8, a person seeking to rely on them will have to be able to discharge the onus of proof in Article 3 (1). The difficulty of doing so is illustrated by the inability of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to agree and adopt the Australian Law Reform Commission's report proposing reforms to the laws of defamation.

Laws enabling courts to order Penalties of imprisonment with hard labour and community work orders are recognised as appropriate limitations on the right not to be held in slavery for servitude contained in Article 8 of the Covenant, but if a challenge to such laws is made in reliance on Article 22 of the Australian Bill of Rights, the person seeking to answer the challenge will have to satisfy Article 3 (1) in addition to relying on qualifications contained in Article 8 of the Covenant. The Law Council of Australia goes right to the heart of this matter, when it comes to that, and says, because of this:

SPEECH.PARA: This departure from the terms of the Covenant raises questions as to the constitutional validity of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill.
Here is an extraordinary situation. Clause 2 of Article 3 says:
A right or freedom set out in this Bill of Rights shall not be limited by any law to any greater extent than is permitted by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

There is a direct reference to the Covenant, although the Law Council of Australia finds some disability in its presentation in this way. But the Article says that there cannot be any limit other than those limits put on by the Covenant.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask again: What does the Senate understand to be `reasonable limitations prescribed by law'? What do the Senate and the Australian people understand as the meaning of the words `demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'? What can that possibly mean? The Government ought not to bring to the people of Australia a Bill of Rights with uncertain meaning in it. As we are told by the Minister, the whole aim of the Bill is to prescribe people's rights so that everyone will know the rights they have, so that they will have no doubt at all about the width of their freedoms--

TALK.START.PARA: —It proscribes.

What kind of country is it whose socialist government invents a Bill which says: `If you want to find your freedoms, litigate them'? I suppose that one would expect that from a socialist government, which thereby creates a government industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that Article 3 (1) renders the whole Bill ineffective because it cannot be precise in what it means. I suppose that the majority of Australian people would devoutly hope that it does. TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that Senator Harradine was perfectly well equipped to give us the first of his 15-minute bursts on the subject without a preliminary springboard from me. However, let me at least go to some of the questions that have been raised so far and other points I can no doubt pick up in the course of debate. It is the case that in many ways Article 3 (1) is probably the most controversial Article in the Bill of Rights. That was the claim I was originally prepared to make, although maybe I will have to adjust it in the light of the three or four hours we seem to have taken on Article 2 so far. Article 3 (1) uses unusual language and an unusual drafting style and, as such, has attracted a degree of resistance from a number of quarters of a fairly predictable kind. However, I make the point right at the outset in passing that the criticism of the Law Council of Australia of this clause was not quite the root and branch comprehensive analysis that I had rather been led to expect from Senator Sir John Carrick's contribution-of which there were really only two or three sentences buried in the text-raising the point rather than coming out with a great deal of virility in support of a different formulation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me explain the rationale for Article 3 in its present form. In order to achieve a Bill of Rights drafted in relatively simple terms that was readily separable from the rest of the Act in which it was contained-that is to say, a group of articles-the drafting device of having one general limitation provision was adopted in preference to specific limitations being set out in the individual articles. Article 3 (1) is that general limitation provision. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) dealt with this matter in his second reading speech, in language that I think bears repetition, when he said:

The desire to have in Australia a broadly worded inspirational charter led to the inclusion in this Bill of a general test of permissible limitations on rights. By Article 3 the rights and freedoms in the Bill of Rights are `subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'. In addition, they shall not be limited to an extent greater than that permitted by the relevant Covenant provisions. This approach, which is similar to the one adopted in the 1982 Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, will allow all reasonable limits necessary in the interests of the community generally and of other individuals. The approach also allows some flexibility and adjustment to current community standards in the limitations which should be permitted in relation to any particular rights.

The terminology of Article 3 (1) has been adopted, as I have just indicated, from the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, section 1 of which is in more or less identical terms. I also indicate that it bears a family resemblance to a number of clauses of the European Convention which talk in terms of `such limitations as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of public safety' and various other values which are there set out. It also bears a family resemblance to clauses, as I recall them, in a number of Bills of Rights-I think of Nigeria in the first instance-which were drafted in association with the British Foreign Office during the stage of Constitution making in the 1960s and subsequently. So the language of this Article is by no means the product of invention by the draftsmen. It has considerable pedigree.

Article 3 (1) has been criticised for introducing a considerable uncertainty into the operation of the Bill of Rights. Senator Sir John Carrick was keen to make that point, the corollary of which is that it places too much power, I suppose the argument goes, in the hands of the judiciary. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills made criticisms of this kind in pages 6 to 8 of its Alert Digest No. 12 of 1985. However, several points can be made in response. I make the point right at the outset that the criticisms by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee were very effectively countered, I believe, by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which concluded in its consideration of this general issue in paragraph 3.55:
. . . the appropriate solution for an Australian Bill of Rights is to deal with derogation expressly in one discrete section . . .
It further concluded in paragraph 3.57:
. . . wording similar to that of Section 1 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms is appropriate.

In respect of the criticism of uncertainty, I think there are two particular points that are worth making. The first point is that in the vast majority of cases what is a reasonable limitation prescribed by law, demonstrably justifiable in a free and democratic society, will be readily ascertainable from the nature of the limitations permitted by the Covenant itself. Article 3 (2) directs attention, of course, quite explicitly back to the language of the Covenant. It will be also ascertainable from the existing case law in Canada, which is already developing quite rapidly, not yet much at the Supreme Court level but certainly at a number of provincial and regional courts-I will be happy to give some illustrations of how that has developed in the context of obscenity law in Canada if that point is raised, as I suspect it might be, in the course of this debate--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am already on top of that.
—I simply make the point in general terms that the Canadian-
—I will take it up; don't you worry about that.

—If Senator Harradine takes it up I will deal with it, but let me just make the point in general terms at the moment that the Canadian courts which have so far dealt with issues of that kind, admittedly at a lower court level only so far, have had no difficulty whatsoever in applying the Canadian equivalent of this language in order to uphold the validity of censorship laws of a kind which there would be general community acceptance here in Australia ought to be upheld.
—That is not true, you know.

—We will deal with that when we get to it. Maybe Senator Harradine can make that one of his contributions to the debate if he is looking for a peg on which to hang it. Another point that I would make in response to the uncertainty criticism is that there will be, of course, at the margin difficult cases. In an instrument such as the Bill of Rights, there will be cases for which the Parliament could not adequately provide in advance and the application of the law in such cases must be left to the courts. That however, is the traditional role of a judiciary and there is no reason to doubt its ability to fulfil it in respect of the Bill of Rights. The notion that the courts are going to have a peculiar difficulty with this language in Article 3 is one, I think, that can be very much overstated. I had the pleasure of a conversation, when in Canada a few weeks ago, with the Chief Justice of the Canadian Supreme Court, His Honour Sir Brian Dickson, and he made the point in response to my direct querying on this issue that he did not think this language would generate great difficulty or great uncertainty and that there had been no particular anxiety expressed about it within the legal profession and within the judicial system to date. He envisaged a number of cases coming forward in which the dimensions of the concept would be tested, but in general he indicated an active willingness to get on with the job and by no means any of the kind of reluctance that one might have expected had one taken literally the approach of Senator Sir John Carrick and those who think like him.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the criticism, to the extent that it is made, that legislative power is being handed to the judiciary-the corollary or extension, as I said, of the uncertainty argument-the Parliament is, in the Bill of Rights, spelling out the fundamental principles it wants applied. It is, in Article 3, indicating the limits in which the courts must work in applying those fundamental principles in particular cases. Again there is a body of international jurisprudence to guide the courts-a body of jurisprudence that the drafters have very much taken into account in the language used. Accordingly, the courts are not being asked to make law but simply to apply it. That is their traditional role. In addition, of course, Parliament will retain the ability to modify the Bill if unanticipated interpretations cause problems. That remains, again, one of the attractions of the legislative Bill of Rights in the first instance rather than an entrenched constitutional one until everyone gets an opportunity to work with these concepts to let them evolve and develop.

The remaining point that was made by Senator Sir John Carrick was about the constitutional validity of this particular drafting approach that has been adopted. As to that, I simply refer first to Article 3 (2), which does make it clear that any derogations from the basic guarantees in the Bill of Rights cannot be greater than the permissible derogations that are attached to most of the individual right stating clauses in the Covenant itself. That is a clear direction not to exceed the permissible boundaries of the limitations on rights which are contained in the Covenant and as such establishes a clear nexus between the statement of rights in the Bill of Rights before us now and the permissible restrictions on those rights as set out in the Covenant. It is the case that it would be possible for rights to be restricted to a less extensive degree in some instances than is permitted by the Covenant. To the extent that the boundary line is drawn around the outer perimeter of the Melbourne Cricket Ground, it would be permissible for a court applying the rights and freedoms of protections in this particular Bill, in order to continue the metaphor, to draw the boundary within which it was prepared to allow limitations somewhere around the half-forward line, I suppose, rather than the outer boundary line.

To the extent that health and morals considerations clearly get caught up in that kind of language, it would not be appropriate for a court to ignore those considerations entirely.

I think that is a further point worth making; that there is an erratic quality to the way in which the various permissible limitations on rights are set out in various clauses.

If Senator Harradine wants all the permissible categories of derogation that appear in one clause or another in the Bill to be set out in the final version of the explanatory memorandum as printed, as I indicated in an earlier debate, the Government is only too happy to oblige.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just said that that would make no difference whatsoever, by implication.
—No, but to the extent that the explanatory memorandum--
—Don't con us.

—Senator Harradine has made the point before and I am simply anticipating that he will make it again, because I expect every arrow in the quiver to be deployed over the next God knows how long it takes. When combined with Article 3, with which we are now dealing, Article 18 says that a person shall not be deprived of life except in a non-arbitrary way in accordance with law and only where demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society. TALK.START.PARA: —Not that I am aware.

—Perhaps the Minister can consider that.
