SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to try to address a number of those specific questions. I apologise if they were asked by Senator Sir John Carrick previously but I was being harangued by Senator Walters and a miscellany of other interveners. I am not sure that I fully heard everything said by Senator Sir John Carrick. I will go through the various questions expressed by Senator Harradine. The first concerns the circumstances or conditions under which limits could be described as reasonable. The short answer is that that is for the courts to determine, having regard not only to that one word `reasonable' as it appears prefacing `limitations', but to the whole construction of the clause. The courts are very good at dealing with the expression `reasonable'. They confront it all the time in other legislative enactments and there is no reason to suppose that they would be any less good in dealing with it in this context. It involves an element of balance rather than strict and literal application of rules of blindingly clear application. I acknowledge that. In the real world situations are very often difficult to deal with by the simple mechanical application of black letter rules. The requirement of reasonableness being determined by the courts is not unusual bearing in mind that reality.

SPEECH.PARA: The second question concerns the meaning of the expression `by law'. It certainly extends to statutes, regulations and rules of common law. It is not intended to be, nor would it be construed by the courts as in any way narrower than that. The third question was about when a limitation is justified-what the word `justified' means. Again, I make the point that that is for the courts to determine, reading the word in context. It is not just `justified'; the Article reads `demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'. That is a further qualification of the concept of a reasonable limitation. It is a reasonable limitation of a particular character, namely, one which can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'. Again, there is no doubt that the courts will quickly evolve a variety of rules of thumb based on jurisprudence in Canada, Europe and elsewhere to assist them in applying that concept to particular cases as they arise.

The fourth question was why the expression `can be' rather than `is' is used in the context of `such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified'. The short answer is that that is the Canadian language. We wanted to make as few variations as possible so that there can be some mutual learning from and application of the developing jurisprudence in each country. I do not personally see that there is any particular significance attachable to that particular linguistic formulation. It is a question of whether the court in each case is satisfied that there is a reasonable limitation prescribed by law and demonstrably justified. The fact that the language of `can be' rather than `is' is used does not affect the likely way in which the courts would react to any particular problem that came before them.

As to the expression `free and democratic society', that is an invitation, certainly, to the courts to have regard, particularly in unusual or difficult cases, to practices or regimes which are applicable in comparable countries, such as Britain, Canada, the United States and elsewhere. It is not a matter of the mechanical application of this particular phrase in such a way as to say that the only country to which that expression is applicable is our own-that would be cultural arrogance of a very high order-nor can one devise a quick and simple checklist to refer to. Essentially, I imagine it is the common law family of countries that would be the most ready and familiar reference point for the courts. There is already reliance on the jurisprudence of the other countries as being of persuasive value in the Australian courts. There is an increasing willingness on the part of our High Court of Australia to look at the American cases, and I imagine that trend will undoubtedly continue in the context of the application of a Bill of Rights.

There has been some interpretation of this clause in Canada as it applies to Canada. In this respect I quote from a report of a case Re Federal Republic of Germany and Rauca which, despite the title, is a case determined by the Ontario Court of Appeal in 1982. That involved a request for extradition in the course of which the court said that it:

. . . must determine what is a reasonable limit demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society by reference to Canadian society and by the application of principles of political science. Criteria by which these values are to be assessed are to be found within the Charter itself, which means that the courts are entitled to look at those societies in which, as a matter of common law, freedoms and democratic rights similar to those referred to in the Charter are enjoyed.

There is an outward looking quality about it but not one that is easily confinable to any particular checklist of countries. One relies here, as elsewhere, on the common sense of the courts. Certainly I do not think that the clause could be read as freezing any given Australian law and saying that, since Australia is by and large a democratic and free society, any law that has ever been passed by any legislature in Australia must therefore be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society within the meaning of Article 3. I do not think that that follows. That is a hurdle requirement, if you like, that has to be met, but it is not the total requirement set by the clause. It is demonstrably justified by reference to the values that one associates with societies that justify that particular description.

I turn to the final point of what is the burden of proof on an aggrieved person. It is a difficult question to answer in the abstract. I am happy to try again if it is raised. It was put by Senator Harradine in the particular context of an argument about the possible application of Article 18 to re-introduction of a death penalty.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. That was a further issue. I raised that in particular but it was put in a specific context by Senator Sir John Carrick in respect of libel laws.

—Perhaps I will have to listen again to Senator Sir John Carrick on the subject of burden of proof because I am not sure that I fully understood the point. Let me deal quickly with the death penalty example because it does pull together some of these threads in the way that Senator Harradine put the case. What he tried to suggest was that the Bill of Rights was no good because, although it purports to protect the right to life, it would not even be good enough to strike down some subsequent introduction of the death penalty in, let us say, the Australian Capital Territory because, of course, the Bill of Rights as presently drafted is applicable only to the Commonwealth and not the States. Senator Harradine said that a Bill of Rights would not be good enough to do that, given the number of loopholes in this clause. His argument went that that was a demonstration of just how weak and what a non-event this Bill of Rights is.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it clear that the Bill of Rights does not in terms outlaw the death penalty-that has been done by other legislation-because the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on which it is based equally does not outlaw the death penalty. To go further here, as elsewhere, than the terms of the Covenant in identifying the right or the language in which the right is expressed would expose the Bill here, as elsewhere, to constitutional challenge. All that the Bill of Rights outlaws is that which the Covenant outlaws, that is, arbitrary deprivation of life. An awful lot hangs on that word `arbitrary'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A condemned man can hang on it too.

—With the utmost respect to Senator Harradine, that is a cheap debating point. I acknowledge that the way in which that clause is drafted, and given the reality that death penalties do exist for better or worse-in my view worse-in societies like the United States which would be generally acknowledged to be free and democratic, it is the case, for one reason or another, putting together the various qualifying expressions in the legislation, that the death penalty would not necessarily be struck down. But I imagine there would still be room for argument by Senator Harradine's condemned man in a number of possible situations about the reintroduction of a law in some jurisdiction which was subject to this Bill of Rights, and one of the arguments may well depend very significantly on the proper application of that expression `arbitrarily deprived of life'. A capital punishment clause of general application which was not limited to particular kinds of offences, or even particular kinds of homicide offences, and which was quite unrestricted in its possible scope and did not respond to different kinds of homicide situations, might well be subject to the same kind of argument that originally appealed to the United States Supreme Court when it, for a period, outlawed the death penalty completely on the ground of the arbitrary application in a number of jurisdictions of rules about the application of the death penalty of uncertain application because a number of death penalty laws as they then existed, unfortunately-they have since been drafted with very much more precision and have withstood subsequent constitutional scrutiny-in a number of United States jurisdictions were so loosely and vaguely worded that in effect their application was almost completely discretionary, depending on the whim or mood of those administering the judicial and punishment system of the particular jurisdiction. Of course, in practice that led to discriminatory patterns emerging where whites and blacks convicted of almost identical crimes in almost identical circumstances were treated differently insofar as the application of the death penalty was concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: If one has a situation in which laws are loosely and vaguely drafted in imposing the death penalty in a sweeping way, one would have a very good argument, I would have thought, based on the language of Article 18 and consistent with the permissible limitations in Article 3, for seeking to strike that down. I am simply responding as well as I can to the particular case that Senator Harradine raised. I am not claiming more for this Bill of Rights than it contains, but nor am I claiming any less. It is perhaps a good way of finishing to make the point that I have so often made before; that a Bill of Rights is not a universal panacea for every conceivable kind of human rights problem that we can anticipate. Here it is not a universal panacea because it does not completely and unequivocally in all conceivable circumstances wipe out the possible reintroduction of the death penalty. That is true. It does not do a lot of other things which demand other specific laws to be achieved. It is not a complete code of conduct in the area of sex or race discrimination. It is nothing like a complete code of effective guidance so far as privacy infringing behaviour is concerned. It needs supplementation so far as the rights of criminal suspects are concerned in all the jurisdictions where that is an issue. All of those things need to be done. The Bill of Rights cannot do the whole job but it does the particular job that we want it to do very well indeed. I do not think that any of the points so far made against it undermine the force of that conclusion.

I turn to case 2, that is, the case of a citizen who wants to rely on the Bill of Rights to defend himself from the application to him of some law, criminal or otherwise, and wants to use the Bill of Rights in the way it is intended, not so much as a sword but as a shield against untoward application of the otherwise applicable law and practice of the state against him. In due course that may require some reference to the evolving body of Australian jurisprudence on what those phrases mean but that is true of all sorts of exercises in statutory interpretation.

—They cannot allow the right to be undermined to a greater extent.
—But what about extended to a further extent?

—There is a primary right which I am holding in my left hand and there are permissible assaults which may be made on that primary right all gathered up in a quiver in my right hand. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some general remarks about Article 3. I want to make it perfectly clear that Article 3 highlights one of the fundamental objections that the Opposition has had to the Bill of Rights Bill and the whole exercise we are now debating. It is one of the reasons why we voted against it at the second reading stage and why we will continue to vote against it in the hope that ultimately common sense will prevail and this Parliament will throw it out. The Government has said that this Bill of Rights has been drafted by it as an inspirational statement for Australians. Senator Evans has indicated a way in which this will inspire Australians. If it is passed it is clear that the Government will embark on a great propaganda campaign. All the schools in the country will have sheets with nice coloured lettering and a little picture of Senator Evans or the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and others saying: `This is what this wonderful Government has given you. We have given you all these statements about your rights'. The Government will not be telling them, of course, that their forebears had these rights for a long period in this country and that the countries from which these people have come have enjoyed rights of this kind, under common law, for a very long time. Those rights were not vouchsafed to them by the Hawke Government or by legislation which the Hawke Government has produced in this Parliament. On many occasions those rights have been very strongly fought for and achieved by people standing up for their own rights at all times.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, the Government has said that this Bill of Rights is supposed to be an inspirational statement. It is becoming pretty clear that it is just another expensive propaganda exercise by the Hawke Government. I remind the Committee that, as far as I can recall, the last inspirational statement we had enshrined in our Constitution was section 92 of the Constitution, which states:
. . . trade, commerce and intercourse . . . shall be absolute free.

We know what an enormous amount of litigation that has engendered. Over the last 80 years-it is so even today-it has been very difficult, when interpreting that section, to be really sure what it means. Indeed, lots of theories are floating around that its interpretation-to the extent that it has any certainty about it now-ought to be radically changed. So, at the outset, I would have thought that parliaments ought to beware of inspirational statements when they are approaching a piece of legislation.

However, what I really want to say is that Article 3 (2) qualifies this inspirational statement-as Senator Evans has said-by the various qualifications that appear throughout the Covenant. Of course, the Government has to do that for constitutional reasons for a start. Senator Evans has already referred to some of the qualifications which appear throughout the Covenant. The Covenant is replete with them. If these qualifications were translated into this Bill of Rights there would not be too much inspiration for anybody. Indeed, very few people would ever be able to understand it, as Senator Evans has said. Once we read through the Covenant we see that there are major qualifications to almost every Article in it. Those qualifications are not always uniform, but they talk about matters such as `in the interests of national security', `public health' and `public morals' and this `ordre public', or public order, translated into English, but that translation does not express the qualification. Senator Evans has already admitted that this concept of a public order in the French sense is very technical. It covers a vast range of matters. At least to some large extent they have been developed in French law. I suppose that if we became experts in French law we would be able to give it some fairly specific meaning and a fairly reasonable answer to any question that arises.

Whatever one may think of this approach to the Bill of Rights, at least we have through that laborious and highly technical process, incorporated in the Bill of Rights and into our legal system, a vast number of qualifications which, although they may be like any other very elaborate statute, have a great deal of potential controversy about them. Nevertheless, there is some yardstick by which the courts can make a decision. But the Government has not been content simply to leave the matter there. It has introduced in Article 3 (1) this enormously vague and quite new approach to statutory interpretation. Already great attention has been focused on this point by the Committee, and I do not want to go over it in any detail again. By saying that in addition to these rights and qualifications in the Covenant the rights and freedoms set out in the Bill can also be subject `to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society', one is introducing by those words into the Covenant an entirely new responsibility to be placed on the judiciary. One has already placed a very severe new burden on the judiciary under Article 3 (2), but at least it has some guidelines it can refer to. At least it has some body of law under the public order concept.

I do not know enough about other legal systems to know how public health matters or morals have been interpreted. Perhaps there is some assistance that can be obtained, but Article 3 (1) contains no guidelines with which the courts are familiar, except as to the word `reasonable'. I concede that obviously the courts have a great deal of experience about what is or is not reasonable, but the concept of what may be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society introduces an entirely new concept for the courts. It assigns to the courts and judges enormous new powers, which no doubt the judges do not want to exercise. They will regard this as an intractable problem for them to deal with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Overtly political criteria.

—As Senator Harradine says, all they will be able to judge is their own political views, which will intrude to an enormous extent into this exercise. Some judges may welcome it, but I am sure the vast majority will be horrified that they have to embark on this sort of investigation. I emphasise that the task given to the courts here is quite different from their ordinary task of statutory interpretation. The broad generalisations of the Covenant are not sufficient by any means, except as may be ascertained from the Covenant itself; they cannot be interpreted in the ordinary sense. They have got to be rewritten and expanded in a very big way by the courts. It is not an ordinary exercise in statutory interpretation that we are leaving to the courts as we do in ordinary legislation. It is a completely new concept, a new power, and a vast new problem that we are handing to the courts by Article 3 in general, and particularly 3 (1) and the extraordinary words that appear in it. The word `demonstrably' seems to me to require proof. I do not know what process of proof the courts are expected to adopt. When the courts come to grapple with what is meant by `a free and democratic society', I think they will be far more bewildered by that even than we are.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a specific instance as to how this might apply, and I would like the Minister to come back to this question. When we were debating our amendment to exclude Norfolk Island from this legislation, I referred to the guarantee of freedom of movement. These are great inspirational phrases that will be emblazoned on every wall in every classroom in Australia-phrases such as `Freedom of movement is the right of persons in Australia'. Every person lawfully in Australia has the right to freedom of movement and choice of residence. People may go to Norfolk Island for a holiday and if it is such a delightful spot, as many people tell me it is-I have not had the pleasure of having been there-they might be minded to settle there. Then they will be confronted with what Senator Evans foreshadowed as government legislation for Norfolk Island or perhaps from this Parliament that will restrict their rights to move there. Senator Evans says: `Norfolk Islanders need not worry about that being struck down because they can rely on Article 3 of the Covenant'. It seems in his mind to be self-evident that it is a major restriction that an Australian citizen will be unable to exercise his right of freedom of movement and choice of residence. Goodness me, if any Australian told us that we could not go and live anywhere in Australia we liked, not only would section 92 of the Constitution be breached-and the meaning has been held to be fairly clear-but we would be outraged. I would hope that the whole country and this Parliament would be outraged at any such restriction being placed upon us.

Here that freedom is being even further enshrined in this Article, but we are told: `Don't worry about that. In fact, it will be able to be restricted because it will be able to be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.' I cannot imagine anything that is more a contradiction in terms than that restriction being placed on a guarantee of the right of freedom of movement and choice of residence. That sums up the awful dilemma we are placing judges in and we are also indicating the sorts of major problems we are creating by passing the legislation in this form.

—I see that Senator Sir John Carrick has now returned to the Committee. That would then shift an onus back to the plaintiff to establish, I guess, to the satisfaction of the court that, notwithstanding the prima facie guarantee of freedom of expression, Article 3 acknowledged permissible limitations and libel law was traditionally one of them. The argument is that this creates a very substantial practical burden and a financial burden to the extent that the plaintiff has to adduce argument, and possibly some supporting evidence as well as mere conceptual argument, in favour of the application of the permissible limitations provision. What has, I think, been overlooked is an important point, however, and that is that the plaintiff in that situation could very properly call in aid the intervention of the Attorney-General to defend the law in question. —It would not be a constitutional matter.

—No-I am just saying, on the analogy of the existing provisions in section 78 of the Judiciary Act, which require notice to be given to the Commonwealth when a constitutional point going to the validity of legislation is in issue, and then the Commonwealth can decide whether to intervene; ditto a State can if a point such as that is in issue. Notice is required to be given so the matter will not pass by default. Equally, there is provision here for that support to be called in aid, and as a practical matter I do not think that there is any doubt but that the Attorney-General's Department and the Solicitor-General will have a good deal more work to do defending Commonwealth laws from this kind of collateral, sideways attack that is made on them from time to time.
—They will be in the courts for every libel case.

—Well, not after the first one is resolved in favour of the defendant, as I am sure it would be, on the sorts of principles that are here in issue. It might be a matter for argument as to where the boundaries of libel law begin and end so far as public figures or something are concerned. There has been a lot of jurisprudence in the United States about that. That has been a healthy argument and one that will be informed in Australia by a lot of that accumulated law elsewhere. This is the kind of issue about which many people have been concerned in the past, arguing that defamation laws may not go far enough in some respects, so far as individual privacy protection is concerned, but in other respects perhaps go too far. This is a topic which could properly be debated in the context of an argument about the application of a Bill of Rights. It is a bit unfair if some private litigant is bearing the cost of that argument being fought out, but that is not a necessary requirement at all.
—It is a back-door method of getting your uniform defamation law.
—Would that it were. No; I have abandoned that, along with many other aspirations.
—Would it apply to existing cases?

—No, it is inconceivable that that could be the case. It will have no retrospective application-except to existing cases that have not yet come to fruition in the courts. I suppose that any common law development that occurs before a particular case is heard and determined--
—That is a retrospective effect. All of those who have libel cases in the Australian Capital Territory, including myself-
—I do not want to give any kerbside advice on the current state of play.
—It is not advice that I am seeking; I want to know whether or not it is retrospective.

—It is not retrospective. It is just that any law that people call in aid, one way or another, is subject in its interpretation and application to the overriding effect of the Bill of Rights, and to that extent it may well be appropriate for the courts to deal with such a matter on particular occasions as they arise. But I would not want to comment on the sort of scenario that Senator Harradine has created unless I had an opportunity to think the matter through further.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded that Senator Harradine has five years within which to finish his litigation because there is a five-year sunrise period, and even the worst administered libel case would, I think, be likely to reach fruition before then. So, as a practical matter, I think that people such as Senator Harradine would be sufficiently put on notice for that not to be a practical problem.

As to Senator Durack's example about Norfolk Island, I acknowledge, quite frankly, that the choice of residence provision in Article 15 is one that might well prove to be, on proper examination, at odds with the existing very tightly controlled immigration and residence laws on Norfolk Island. I do not think that the case is quite as open and shut as Senator Durack would make out. There are, for example, in every jurisdiction of Australia, zoning laws which limit a person's choice of residence, based on a variety of considerations about the capacity of the infrastructure to support residence in particular areas and, of course, the particular character of the land use, area by area, that is involved. An argument might well be able to be constructed, on the analogy of zoning laws, that the condition and size of Norfolk Island are such that it can support only a very limited number of permanent residents, and that it is consistent with the kind of ground rules that one would expect to emerge in a democratic society that there be some kind of queueing system identified for the taking up of those scarce places. It might be possible for an argument of that kind to be constructed. But it must be frankly acknowledged that the choice of residence matter is perhaps the one aspect of Norfolk Island law and practice at the moment which there might be some good ground, based on the idiosyncratic history of that place, for retaining but which may run into trouble with the Bill of Rights.

It is against that background that I mentioned the other day, when this became an issue, that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) had indicated a willingness to look at the application of the Bill to Norfolk Island so far as matters such as tax laws and, more particularly, immigration laws were concerned. It was against that background that he wrote as follows to the Chief Minister, and I shall now put the letter on the record because I have had an opportunity-as I did not have last time-to check with him. The relevant paragraph is this:

I confirm that I undertook that, if the operation of the Bill of Rights results in jeopardy to the existing legal arrangements in the areas of local immigration and taxation measures, then I would support the enactment of specific overriding provisions if necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you think that you will get that through the Senate?

—Because we shall take on board Senator Durack's very sincerely expressed concern for the protection of the citizens and culture of Norfolk Island. We can argue out the merits of it, but that is an expression of willingness to acknowledge that there are particular situations which may arise from time to time where there is no clear in-principle reason why the full possible literal force of the Bill of Rights should apply and where a case might be able to be made for some sort of overriding provision. A number of such cases will arise from time to time. That is another one of the advantages in proceeding, at least for a decade or so, I would argue, by way of legislation rather than entrenched constitutional provisions which are not subject to this kind of flexibility. I do not think that there will be very much of a patchwork quilt at the end of the day if we go down this particular track. The desire to apply the Bill of Rights to Norfolk Island was, for the overwhelming part, that the guarantees of freedom of expression and association, of privacy and rights in relation to criminal process, are equally apt and appropriate to be enjoyed by the citizens of Norfolk Island as those anywhere else. There are some particular aspects of this which may need to be thought through, and I have indicated a willingness on the part of the Government to do just that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister thought my language a little robust. The more I think about this matter-I have been thinking about his reply-the more I realise the very great danger inherent in this situation. One reason was presentational efficacy, believing that placing the general limitation at the head of the list in Article 3 would be enough to signal that they were not absolutes but subject to qualification. The second reason was that we believed quite genuinely that the language of each of the articles of the Covenant was no less vague and imprecise in its application and was of no greater assistance to the ordinary person reading the provision than was the language that we chose to have generalised application in Article 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is dealing with Article 3 of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 and the answers that have been given by the Minister. The question that I raised just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner was to attempt to clarify precisely what Article 3 (2) means-whether Article 3 (2) means that in the administration and in the interpretation of the Bill of Rights the limitations set down in the Bill of Rights Schedule-that is, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights-are applicable in respect of the particular articles in which they are contained. I believe that there is some misunderstanding around the chamber about that very aspect. I understand Senator Sir John Carrick put the question to the Minister and the Minister responded in a way that seemed to indicate to Senator Sir John Carrick that the court or the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission would need to have regard to the limitations contained in the Covenant in respect of the interpretation of specific articles in the Bill of Rights. Clearly that is not so, by virtue of the wording of Article 3 (2), which says:

SPEECH.PARA: A right or freedom set out in this Bill of Rights shall not be limited by any law to any greater extent than is permitted by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

I have been drawing the distinction between limitations and extensions. The point has been made by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that the operative limitations really are if they `are subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'. That is in Article 3 (1). Article 3 (2) states:
A right or freedom set out in this Bill of Rights shall not be limited by any law to any greater extent than is permitted by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

It seems to me that the limitations in Article 1 are the operative limitations, provided they go up to and including the limitations in the Schedule, in the ICCP. If they happen to fall short of those limitations, there is no problem as far as the interpretation is concerned, but one has to understand that that is not the same thing as saying that the limitations in the Covenant apply to the articles in the Bill, because they do not.

I think Senator Sir John Carrick raised previously the importance of such limitations as the respect of the rights or reputations of others, the protection of national security, public order, public health or morals. Those questions were validly raised by him. Senator Sir John Carrick raised very firmly the freedom of expression provisions question and asked for the Minister's answer: What happens when a person has been slandered, there has been a defamation of a person in the Australian Capital Territory and that person prosecutes a case for defamation under existing defamation laws in the Australian Capital Territory? The Minister at the table has said that, yes, the defendant in that case may appeal under Article 7-the freedom of expression Article-and that the law under which the plaintiff is seeking redress has a reasonable limitation on the freedom of expression, prescribed by law as `as can demonstrably be justified in a free and democratic society'. The onus is on the plaintiff.

What is the test? The plaintiff then has an added test, besides all the other tests that he has to go through on the defamation law, to prove that the defamation laws themselves `can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'. We have heard the Minister say that it is not just our democratic society that he is talking about; it is the United Kingdom, Canada and the United States of America. The plaintiff is going to have a very, very difficult task, indeed, to meet the United States test of freedom of expression, but we have heard from the Minister that it is available to the defendant in a defamation case to appeal under the Bill of Rights and then to place the onus of proof on the plaintiff that in fact the law is `demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'. In answering one of my interjections the Minister said that of course all the rules of evidence would apply. In this case, what are the rules of evidence?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not of evidence, rules of argument. They are two different things-argue by reference to the state of law without adducing evidence.

—We will come to that matter in regard to the criminal law as well. That is another aspect, but in this case the plaintiff will have an uphill battle to prove on that test of `demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society' that the defamation law is `demonstrably'-whatever that means-`justified in a free and democratic society'.
—That is a reverse onus.
—Yes. It gets to the stage where we really have to look at the laws of defamation in the United States and Canada. On the Minister's own admission we have to look at not only our democratic--
—I did not say anything of the kind-that you had to. I said you can have regard to. That is very different from saying that you have to look at it. Come on. Stop distorting.
—In answer to the question that I raised the Minister said--
—`It would be possible to have regard to' is what I said.

—I remind the Minister of what I asked. Does `free and democratic society' refer to Australia alone or does it include other free and democratic societies? I went on by asking what would happen to a longstanding Australian law or practice which is not followed outside Australia. The Minister said that of course the court would have regard to the family of common law nations, and he cited Britain, Canada and the United States as being amongst those countries.
—As permissible reference points.

—Yes, and the Minister specifically stated that those words were taken from the Canadian legislation and that the courts would have regard to what was determined in the Canadian context in that test in its legislation. So in the Minister's words there would be some inter-relationship between the development of the law in that country and this country. I will get to the point. That is the `free and democratic society' test. Article 19 of the Covenant talks about freedom of expression. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The exercise of the rights provided for in paragraph 2 of this article carries with it special duties and responsibilities. It may therefore be subject to certain restrictions, but these shall only be such as are provided by law and are necessary:
(a) For respect of the rights or reputations of others-

Cannot the Minister see that that would be an entirely different test to be applied by the courts in this case? The plaintiff could argue quite forcefully that the defamation laws were appropriate for the aspect of the rights and reputations of others. Clearly, that is the basis of our defamation laws, so that the rights and reputations of others are properly safeguarded by statute. We are placing on the plaintiff a test which it is almost impossible for that plaintiff to sustain. If the Minister is fair dinkum in saying that this Bill will give effect to the Covenant, he will, as far as freedom of expression is concerned, make the point that the freedom-the rights provided for in that Article-carried with it special duties and responsibilities and that it may therefore be subject to certain restrictions. These will only be those provided for by law and necessary for the respect of the rights or reputations of others and for the protection of national security or of public order or of public health or morals.

To test this matter all I need do is ask the Minister. In this case about which we are talking would the plaintiff be able to sustain his rights under challenge by the defendant on the basis of freedom of expression? Would he be able to say that the defamation laws of the Australian Capital Territory are necessary for the protection of the rights or reputations of others? If he could prove that, would he also have to prove that that law was demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society?

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the remarks made by Senator Harradine and Senator Sir John Carrick that there is real confusion about the way that these two quite separate tests will apply. They are set out in a strange order. TALK.START.PARA: —`Be required'; I think that was it.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic difficulty, and a reason, among others, why this clause is drafted as it is-this is to elaborate on an answer I earlier gave to Senator Sir John Carrick-is that the language of so many of those Covenant qualifications is so wide, so loose, that if literally interpreted to their fullest possible extent they would empty the parent rights of all content. What is left of the right of freedom of association or freedom of expression in the context of public demonstrations and so on if we apply the concept to its fullest possible extent? That is the French concept of ordre public. What would be left of the right of freedom of association and expression in public places if we even implied a Queensland interpretation of what public order considerations properly demand, properly entitle. Senator Harradine, wearing his old trade unionist hat, would want to argue very vigorously against some of the possible interpretation of concepts like public order as they could be applied to empty rights of content. What content would one give to the expression `rights of others', again in relation to freedom of association and freedom of expression in a public place, if one was minded to give it the fullest possible interpretation? One could say that the traffic laws of each jurisdiction in Australia, when read literally and absolutely, prohibit any kind of obstruction whatsoever, be it of a footpath or a roadway. Construed absolutely literally, the rights of others to stand or walk exactly where they want to are being infringed by any gathering of more than three people in a public place to express a view about something. This is the problem. If we apply each one of those avenues available in its absolute literal terms, as it appears in the Covenant, we can literally drive a coach and horses through the rights themselves.

I go back to what I said before. The primary objective of the International Covenant and of this Bill of Rights is to protect the rights of individuals. That is clearly what the Covenant is all about, and constitutionally that is what this legislation is all about. The Government has taken the view that, provided we stay within the ball park established by those permissible limitations in the Covenant and provided we capture the essential spirit of what those permissible limitations are, we are implementing the Covenant in good faith for constitutional purposes by doing it the way we are doing it in a way that much better protects individual rights from the kind of depredations that Australian and other governments have wanted to place on them than we would if we went down the route favoured by Senator Sir John Carrick and apparently Senator Harradine of spelling out in elaborate detail every single one of the bits of language in the Covenant and attaching them to each particular right as it appears. Quite apart from all the presentational disadvantages there is that substantive disadvantage involved and that is why we have gone down track we have. I hope that that is sufficient an answer to all the points the honourable senator has raised.

The Minister is requiring the courts to apply an overtly political criterion test to the Bill of Rights. I remind the Committee of something said by the former Chief Justice of Tasmania, Sir Stanley Burbury:
I do not wish to be misunderstood when I say that I do not think it possible to establish a court which we could trust with such a solemn judicial task--
That is the interpretation of a Bill of Rights. He went on:

The interpretation and application by any court of fundamental laws necessarily expressed in wide general terms leaves an immense area for the exercise of judicial discretion and for sharp differences of opinion between judges. Nor can many decisions in this area be based on bare legal reasoning. The personal attributes of the judge will often be stronger factors in moulding his opinion, his social, religious, political, philosophical and cultural background and beliefs. Complete objectivity is impossible. That is the challenge with which we are faced by this Government. That is the challenge about which we are reacting and it is necessary to test this again, and I make no apology for the questions I ask. If one looks at all the articles and applies the Article 3 test to the other articles, what has one left? Each article read with Article 3 means as follows. It means that a person has a right to X-say, freedom of expression-unless that right is cut down by law and the cutting down is demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society. So, questions as to reversal of the onus of proof in criminal matters and all the rest of those sorts of principles that we hold dear just do not arise in this way. He has got to do more than simply put that in issue. He has to make some credible legal argument before the magistrate or the court hearing the particular matter will even ask the other side for some responding argument to that particular assertion. A person cannot walk out of the door of a court by simply saying `I claim that this particular offence for which I am being prosecuted is in breach of articles under the Bill of Rights', and then sit down, smugly folding his hands, throwing the onus on the other side, in the sense that unless the other side--

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that.

—Senator Harradine says that he understands that. The question just does not arise in that way. It is a credible matter that has to be put in issue, and if a credible argument is made that there is some matter in issue here, a credible response would have to be made. I should like to spend a few minutes, because this matter of obscenity has been raised, in just indicating that it is a good case study how this particular problem of pornography and obscenity has been handled in Canada when claims have been made that people's right to freedom of expression has been offended. Let us look at the way in which the Canadian equivalent of our Article 3 (1) has been applied. It is a very instructive example. None of the cases has yet reached the Supreme Court. They have all been resolved at provincial or local level; or perhaps in the provincial court of appeal-no, maybe not. But I am advised that in no single case has any pornography law of any kind actually been struck down, although a number have come before the courts, because it is a fairly obvious sort of pitch to be making. It is already clear that obscenity laws, provided only that they are sufficiently precise, are permissible limitations in Canada on the freedom of expression embodied in section 2(B) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The Chief Justice of British Columbia, His Honour Justice Nemetz, expressed the overall position very succinctly in the case of R. v. Red Hot Video Ltd. The citation is 1985, 18 Canadian Criminal Cases (3D) 1 AT 4-5. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: For centuries democratic societies have set certain limits to freedom of expression. Libel and slander are two such limitations.
That picks up our earlier debate. He continued:
Obscenity is also a limitation. As Mr Justice Dickson (now Chief Justice of Canada) said in Queen against Great West News Ltd, Mantell and Mitchell-
and here he quotes the Chief Justice-

All organised societies have sought in one manner or another to suppress obscenity. The right of the state to legislate to protect its moral fibre and well-being has long been recognised, with roots deep in history. It is within this frame that the courts and judges must work.
Justice Nemetz continued:
Again, the learned Chief Justice considered the scope of free speech under the old Canadian Bill of Rights-
the old 1959 Canadian Bill of Rights-
. . . and said this in part, in the case of the Queen against Prairie Schooner News Ltd:

Freedom of speech is not unfettered either in criminal law or in civil law. The Canadian Bill of Rights was intended to protect, and does protect, basic freedoms of vital importance to all Canadians. It does not serve as a shield behind which obscene matter may be disseminated without concern for criminal consequences. The interdiction of the publications which are the subject of the present charges in no way trenches upon the freedom of expression which the Canadian Bill of Rights assures.

Two cases in this area of which I am further aware have involved challenges to section 159 of the Canadian criminal code: The Queen v. Red Hot Video Ltd, which I cited earlier, and the Queen v. Ramsingh et al in 1984. Section 159 of the Canadian criminal code proscribes, among other things, obscene matter which is defined to include:
Any publication a dominant characteristic of which is the undue exploitation of sex, or of sex and any one or more of the following subjects, namely, crime, horror, cruelty and violence.

In each of the two cases I have mentioned section 159 was held to be a permissible limitation on the Charter's freedom of expression and the accused in each case were held to have been properly convicted of offences under section 159 relating to obscene films. In both cases, the courts upheld section 159 because it was a quite precise provision, readily capable of application to particular cases. In this regard Justice Anderson, on page 11 of the Red Hot Video case, quoted with emphasis the following passage from the judgment of the European Court of Human Rights in the Sunday Times v. United Kingdom Government (1979), European Human Rights Reports 245 at 271, where the Court was considering the contents of the phrase `prescribed by law'. The passage is as follows:

A norm cannot be regarded as a `law' unless it is formulated with sufficient precision to enable the citizen to regulate his conduct: He must be able-if need be with appropriate advice-to foresee, to a degree that is reasonable in the circumstances, the consequences which a given action may entail.

It was because of a lack of precision that the Ontario High Court of Justice in the case of Ontario Film and Video Appreciation Society v. Ontario Board of Censors in 1983, 147 Dominion Law Reports (3D) 58-this is the only case that has gone the other way-decided that a power vested in the Ontario Board of Censors to `censor any film' and `to approve, prohibit or regulate the exhibition of any film in Ontario' conflicted with the Charter. This was because there were no criteria having the force of law which governed the exercise of the Board's discretion. The Court said:

It is not enough to authorize a board to censor or prohibit the exhibition of any film of which it disapproves. That kind of authority is not legal for it depends on the discretion of an administrative tribunal . . . this does not mean that the censorship schemes set out in the theatres act is invalid. Clearly the classification scheme by itself does not offend the charter. Nor do we find that ss. 3, 35 and 38 are invalid, but the problem is that standing alone they cannot be used to censor or prohibit the exhibition of films because they are so general, and because the detailed criteria employed in the process are not prescribed by law.

Similarly-this is Senator Harradine's issue-it has been held that a prohibition on the importation of `immoral or indecent' material, where those terms are not defined in the legislation, is not permissible under the Canadian Charter. On that occasion, the Federal Court of Appeal, in re Luscher v. Deputy Minister, Revenue Canada, Customs and Excise in 1985 said:
A limitation which is vague, ambiguous, uncertain, or subject to discretionary determinations is, by that fact alone, an unreasonable limit.

A few other cases apparently have been decided under the Charter in this area, but the cases to which I have referred-there have been no others going in a completely different direction-disclose a clear and, I suggest to the Senate, very sensible and understandable pattern. In the first place, laws which proscribe obscenity, provided they are sufficiently specific for the citizen to know what is lawful and what is unlawful, will be permissible. Censorship laws which are successfully challenged will be invalidated, not because they can be used to prohibit obscenity, but because they are so vague and ill-defined that they are capable of outlawing material that could not in any way be regarded as obscene. It seems to me that if that sort of approach were adopted by Australian courts under the Australian Bill of Rights-we know have an accumulation of authority under the Canadian Bill which makes that certainly, I guess, more likely than not-it would be an eminently acceptable course to follow. I think that is an instructive canter through the Canadian cases because so much can be made in the abstract about these generalised expressions, where so much depends in practice on the common sense of those applying it.

I make the point-the hoary old chestnut about judicial legislation-which really is to repeat a point that has been crucial to the Government's presentation of the whole Bill of Rights from the outset, that the final word on any question involving the application of this Bill will be left to the elected Parliament. If the Parliament does not like the way in which the courts interpret the phrase `demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society' in some particular case, it is up to this Parliament to act accordingly to correct some clear and obvious misapprehension of the law. The last word is not with the judges, but with the Parliament. That is a tremendously important point to be making and restating in principle whenever the point is made about judicial legislation and judges going off on some frolic of their own, which was the centrepiece of Senator Durack's contribution.

I make my last point in response to Senator Durack and remind him of what Lord Scarman has said on the question of the political pressures on judges, because I think it very neatly encapsulates the point-not that it should need encapsulating in the Australian context where judges have been long familiar with passing upon matters of high political significance in their role as interpreters of the Constitution. In the British context, where this role is much less familiar for judges, Lord Scarman said:

We can, therefore, dismiss as completely unsound such objections as those which, frequently heard in the United Kingdom, are variations on the theme that judges must not be brought into the political arena. They are there already-as umpires, not gladiators or competitors. They have always been there and there they will remain. There is nothing inappropriate in requiring judges to decide justiciable issues arising in a political struggle: and no reason for judges not to be trusted to act judicially and according to law, though the case raises political as well as legal questions.

That is as succinct a statement as one could possibly find. To suggest that the Australian judges are incapable of acting judicially in accordance with the guidelines that will be given to them under the Bill of Rights is to express something which I think is simply not based on fact.

If one wants to know the parameters of power of the Bill of Rights one refers to Article 3 (2), which refers one to the Covenant in which will be found the head of power within which one can manoeuvre but nowhere beyond it. Nowhere can I find within the Covenant anything that relates to Article 4 (2). That is a considerable worry in itself because, whereas Article 4 (1) is expressed in sufficiently wide terms, as I understand it, to guarantee the rights of which Article 4 (2) refers, Article 4 (2) adds nothing to Article 4 (1) but has the capacity to detract from the equal protection of the law guaranteed by Article 4 (1). In other words, the rights guaranteed by the first part of Article 4 are subject to the group rights favoured by the government of the day and permitted by Article 4 (2). Therefore, Article 4 (2) acknowledges that at different times there may be different forms of group rights.

I put to the Minister that this is hardly consistent with the notion that the Bill of Rights provides a charter of fundamental freedom. There is no equivalent provision in the Covenant that I can see. Indeed, Article 26 of the Covenant, upon which Article 4 is obviously based, is expressed in terms which are different from Article 4 (2). Article 26 prohibits any form of discrimination whereas Article 4 (2) permits certain kinds of discrimination. Article 4 (2) therefore, in my view, and certainly in the view expressed by the Law Council of Australia, should be deleted.

But there is a much wider problem than that. If one were to look at clause 47 of the Bill, which we will come to later, it seeks to protect the Bill from any illegality or unconstitutionality of a part. It states:

If this Act exceeds the powers of the Parliament by reason of the inclusion in the Bill of Rights of a particular provision or particular provisions, this Act is intended to operate as if that provision, or those provisions, as the case may be, were omitted from the Bill of Rights.

The difficulty there is one that I foresee, as does the Law Council. It points out that clause 47 therefore has capacity to create difficulties of interpretation and that these difficulties are best exemplified by reference to Article 4 (2). The Law Council of Australia states:

Because of the objects it seeks to achieve Article 4.2 is reasonably pervasive and the fact of its inclusion or omission may affect the manner in which other Articles might be interpreted. Article 4.2 is designed to ensure that laws which permit benign discrimination or affirmative action are not invalidated by reason of other clauses in the A.B.R. Its operation will therefore colour the manner in which the courts will interpret and apply certain of the rights and freedoms set out in the A.B.R. This is emphasised by clause 4 (5) which deals with internal conflicts in the A.B.R. If, as clause 47 contemplates, Article 4.2 is omitted because it exceeds the legislative powers of the Federal Parliament, its omission will alter the thrust of the A.B.R. from one which permits benign discrimination to one which asserts (as does the Covenant) the equal protection of the law without discrimination referred to in Article 4.1. In short, it is not always possible simply to omit invalid Articles from the A.B.R. without significantly altering the operation of the A.B.R. The intended operation of Clause 47 draws attention in another way to the desirability of the A.B.R. adhering more closely to the Covenant (which it is intended to implement) and to the difficulties which could flow from the inclusion of Article 4.2 (which has no counterpart in the Covenant and which appears to compete with Article 26 in the Covenant. . . Although Clause 47 is designed to prevent successful constitutional challenge to the Bill, it is possible that, for the reasons, set out above, a court would hold that Article 4.2 was so pervasive in its effect as to be incapable of severance from the Bill and that the entire Bill was therefore beyond the legislative power of the Parliament.

Let us have a little look at that, because they are very important words indeed. I go back to the Minister's arguments on Article 3. He cannot have it both ways. He says that each of the parts of the 32 articles must be related by Article 3 (2) to the overriding influence and domination of the Covenant itself and therefore they stand as valid, they stand in their limitations and their strengths, by that test. I invite the Minister to tell me where in the Covenant one finds Article 4 (2). I think he will agree that it does not exist and that nowhere is there given an embracing qualification for the whole of the Bill of Rights, bringing about the ability to apply affirmative discrimination-discrimination in favour of people.

This seems to me to be an incredible paragraph that has been inserted. The first provision is, in itself, clearly within the Covenant. It says that every person has the right without discrimination to the equal protection of the law. The fact of the matter is that that is a goal, a pious hope. Let me simply say that certainly within this country not every person has the right without discrimination to the equal protection of the law. The poor may apply for legal aid and the rich may have the money, but there is a middle ground of people who cannot afford access and therefore this provision in itself at this moment is not exactly a full protection for those people. Nevertheless, if we are dealing simply with principles it is within the Covenant. Article 4 (2) is not within the Covenant, on my reading of the Bill, and indeed upon the reading of the Australian Law Council. It is further evidence of the great danger of bringing forward a Bill which becomes a feast for lawyers, which really threatens immediately the constitutionality of the Bill and which, when ordinary people try to read it, has no meaning. How can it have a meaning? If ordinary people read it, how are they to know that fundamentally it is not part of the Covenant itself?

This is the dilemma that I raised earlier this afternoon. We have an article standing on its own and purporting to be legal and constitutional under the head of power. How can it be otherwise? The Government has said that this whole Bill stands on its feet because it comes under the treaty power, clause 51 (xxix), of the Commonwealth Constitution. It says that we can get these powers if we go to the International Covenant. Yet there is no doubt that the second paragraph of Article 4 has no head of power within the Covenant. I invite the Minister to direct his attention specifically to where I will find that head of power which governs the inclusion of Article 4 (2).

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that Senator Sir John Carrick continues to take the strict view he has just articulated about the need for each provision in the Bill to have a precise co-relative base in the Covenant when we get to things like the proposal to insert a right to property, a right to education and a number of other bits and pieces.

It is designed to pick up and apply the rights contained in the Covenant and its constitutional validity will be much enhanced to the extent that it conforms in every respect with the Covenant. However, that does not imply or entail that every statement in this legislation needs slavishly to adhere to the literal expression of the right, or the qualification of the right, as we have just been debating with respect to Article 3, that appears in the Covenant itself. SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the specific point raised, it is the case that there is no specific language that one can find in the Covenant on which Article 2 directly draws from the chosen mode of expression. However, that is true in a sense of both Article 1 and Article 4 of the Bill of Rights. Two provisions in the Bill of Rights deal with equality matters-Article 1 and Article 4. There are two provisions in the Covenant-Article 2 and Article 26. It is not the case that there is a precise correlation in the drafting of the Bill of Rights provisions with the literal language that appears in those two articles in the Covenant, for the reason, as I sought to explain on another day when we were debating this, that the articulation of equality guarantees is a notorious area of conceptual confusion in Bills of Rights, in both international and national documents. There is a terrible tendency to mix up the different concepts and express them in an obscure way. We have reached into the equality rights as expressed jointly by Article 2 and Article 26 of the Covenant and drawn from them the essence, as we perceive it, of those equality guarantees there set out. We have then expressed that essence in two separately defined and drafted clauses.

Honourable senators will recall that Article 1 of our Bill of rights expresses the principle of equality before the law-the notion, as we debated previously, that no one, be he ever so high or ever so low, is entitled to ignore the law or is able to escape the application of the law. The corollary is that the law, as it is set out in this Bill of Rights and the rights and guarantees therein are equally applicable to everyone, whoever they are and whatever their status. That is one concept. The other concept is the Article 4 concept of equal protection of the laws. As I said earlier and I repeat now, this is a much more substantive guarantee to ensure that everyone is, at least prima facie, treated equally in the same substantive way. No one is given any differential advantages, no one is given any differential disadvantages. That equal protection guarantee is not, however, one that can be enjoyed without qualification because laws of all kinds need to discriminate between people for a whole variety of good reasons. It is the case that equal protection laws in the United States and other jurisdictions where they exist have always been interpreted as justifying differential treatment provided there is some objective and reasonable justification for the different treatment. As a primary principle, like cases are treated alike.

The notion of reasonable grounds for different treatment is one that is absolutely inherent in the concept of equal protection of the law. For the purposes of clarification and to put some of these principles and their application beyond doubt, the Government has decided-this may prove to be constitutionally risky and that is a risk that the Government for ill or better has chosen to take-to go one step further and draw out and articulate, as part of its expression of what equality clauses are all about, one further corollary of the equal protection concept; that is to say, not only can laws of differential application be justified when there is some reasonable basis for doing it but specifically laws can be designed as the clause states to discriminate `in favour of a class of persons for the purpose of redressing any disabilities particularly suffered by that class or arising from discrimination against that class'. Laws that can satisfy that description will be regarded, in effect, as laws for which there is reasonable justification. That is on the basis of a whole pattern of interpretation in the United States and elsewhere which says that some degree of benign discrimination is in fact permissible. It is part of the whole philosophical concept of equal treatment that affirmative action or benign discrimination, unequal treatment but for some good reason which favours not only in a negative way but also, on occasions, in a positive way, can be justified in principle. If anyone is interested in the subject, I wrote a very learned and lengthy article on it about a decade ago. It appears at page 26, 1974, volume 6, Federal Law Review called `Benign Discrimination and the Right to Equality'. That explains the principal justification for this drafting. At the time I thought it was a pathbreaking article. It involved a comprehensive analysis of different philosophical contents. Like most other things in my past it seems to have drifted into the mist. What I am trying to say simply is: The equality concept is a complicated one.

TALK.START.PARA: —If only you were dead you would be an authority.

—I am working at it, seeing how the Opposition is treating this piece of legislation, but I will take a few with me when I go. What I am trying to say is that there is not a neat one-to-one correlation between the language of the equality of rights as they appear in the Bill of Rights and those that appear in the Covenant. There are certain things that are implicit in the concept of equal protection which can, among other things, be spelt out in the way in which they are spelt out in Article 4(2).

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1982, as Minister for Education, I had the pleasure of receiving applications from His Lordship Bishop Muldoon, as he then was, and from Catholic education authorities for the establishment of a Catholic secondary school on the central coast of New South Wales.
