But when it comes to a simple matter of a 25 per cent rebate on electricity charges for pensioners, that is not possible.

There seems a certain irony that in Queensland we have a minority government essentially of elderly men. One would think that if there were an advantage in having a government of elderly men, it might well be that they could understand the needs of the aged in that State and that, because they themselves are elderly, they might be in a better position to plan for the senior citizens of that State. But a geriatric regime in Queensland does not, apparently, recognise the needs of the elderly. There is also a certain irony about Queensland-`Life is great in the Sunshine State', and it is supposed to be a great place to retire. Again, it is a good place to retire if one has the sort of income that allows one to buy the support of the Queensland Premier so that one can be on the right side of that Government; but if one is seeking just normal benefits, one will not find that there is very much offering, as I shall detail in a few moments. I would wonder today whether any of those pensioners who have spoken out about the need for electricity charge rebates will find that writs are issued against them, as happened to Opposition members who spoke out about the revocation of a national park in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park area.

Let us look at Queensland's commitment to pensioner concessions. I should like to refer to a very interesting document that has been prepared by the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat in the Department of Social Security. It is called `Pensioner Fringe Benefits: Their Range, Cost and Value'. I have not had a great deal of time to go through it this evening, but I had time to discover that Queensland spends only approximately half the allocation of other States in terms of pensioner fringe benefits. On the most recent available figures, Queensland, with the third largest population in the country, spends less than South Australia or Western Australia. In the 1982-83 period, New South Wales spent $184.1m, Victoria spent $113.3m, South Australia spent $50.5m, Western Australia spent $41.5m, and Queensland spent only $31.1m. Of course, the Commonwealth expenditure was way over and above that, being in excess of $1,583.2m. On average, the other States spent approximately $30 per head on pensioner concessions, whilst Queensland spent only about $15 per head-about half of all other States.

I should like to run through some of the differences between the States. I certainly propose to do this in more detail, but I think that on the day that pensioners have been shut out of their own parliament, it is appropriate just to run through the differences between the States. In regard to health, whereas ambulance services are provided free in New South Wales and Victoria, there is a concessional subscription in Queensland. In regard to home purchase and mortgage interest relief, more stringent conditions are applied in Queensland. In regard to rent relief, there are bond guarantees to the landlord only, and, of course, many real estate agents and landlords will simply not deal with government in regard to accepting rent relief because they are fearful of bureaucracy; they just cannot be bothered. That compares with rent subsidies of up to 20 per cent in a number of States and advance rents and bonds that are given to pensioners in other areas. In regard to rate rebates, in Queensland they are only 20 per cent, compared with up to 60 per cent in a number of other States. Furthermore, in Queensland there is no rebate on water and sewerage charges.

Electricity charge rebates are what Queensland pensioners were lobbying for today. They are not available in Queensland; neither are gas charge rebates. There are no airline fare concessions in Queensland, as compared with Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Tasmania. There are no concessions on driver's licence fees. The motor vehicle registration concession is less than the concessions in other States. Even when it comes to aids and appliances, benefits are means-tested and referral is necessary, which makes access to aids and appliances more difficult than it is in a number of other States. Whereas New South Wales has a special concession to help elderly people in regard to moving from one home to another, with a furniture removal concession allowance, and whereas there are heating allowances in a number of these tables, one can see that Queenslanders generally are worse off in regard to public rental housing and domiciliary care.

Therefore, I take the opportunity to commend the Acting Minister for Community Services, the Hon. Brian Howe, who has announced tonight grants in excess of $1.5m for home and community care in Queensland. These initiatives in home and community care for the frail aged and disabled will be introduced in Queensland following this allocation by the Commonwealth. The allocation will assist five projects to provide a wide range of support services to enable aged and disabled people to be maintained in the community rather than being prematurely or inappropriately admitted to an institution. That is just the first of the allocations under the home and community care scheme, and I assure the Acting Minister that they will be very much welcomed in a State that is not committed to spending on assistance for the elderly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard Senator Reynolds's litany of the bad deal that pensioners are reported to get in Queensland, I wonder why so many Australians are retiring to Queensland. It is a remarkable thing. The statistics show a big move of retired people to Queensland. However, that is not the issue I wish to raise. I want to deal with a matter which should be of major concern to the Senate-an attempt to deprive the Senate and honourable senators of the capacity to inquire properly into the functionings of a government department and, in particular, of a project, the community employment program, run by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has applied an information clampdown as a result, I understand, of the activities of the Waste Watch Committee, of which I am Chairman. It is even now impossible to receive information about what was in Press releases put out by that Department. An officer of that Department advised my office today that he had been instructed that there should be no response to questions from me or my office and that every request for information must go through the Minister's office or should be placed through appropriate channels, such as questions on notice or questions without notice in the Senate. There are, of course, and have been, many questions on notice, particularly in the other House, relating to this program which have been unsatisfactorily answered. As a result, there have been applications for information under the Freedom of Information Act made by, for example, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Neil Brown. We heard in the Senate today the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) say that if Senator Brown--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Brown.
—Mr Brown-
—There are enough of you people coming up here from the Reps.

—We are trying to uplift the tone. Senator Walsh said that if Mr Brown wished to proceed with his application he would be obliged to pay a fee for it on a fee for service basis. The Minister went on at some length in a statement today to try to justify this incredible attempt to prevent the proper exercise of a parliamentarian's duty in finding out information to assist the good government of this country. Point C in the list Senator Walsh released says that among the criteria to be applied when considering whether a fee should be charged for the provision of information under the freedom of information legislation was `whether the giving of access was in the general public interest or in the interests of a substantial section of the public'. One would have thought that when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition seeks information on such a public matter as that, the fact that it would be of interest to a substantial section of the public or in the general public interest would be self-evident. It was not, however, to Senator Walsh.
—A cover-up.
—It is a cover-up and a disgusting attempt to cover up clear incompetence, inefficiency and waste. The response by Senator Walsh was this:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Brown has not justified remission of the charges in the public interest. He has not provided any evidence to support remission on these grounds. He has not indicated that the information will, in fact, be provided to the public. Further, a decision to remit the charge is not consistent with the Government's policy to limit the costs of administration of the FOI Act, nor with the general principle of user pays.

Senator Walsh is hiding behind any excuse he can to prevent the proper exercise of a parliamentarian's duty. I must say that I think it is outlandish. It is a disgrace. I hope that the Senate will decide to take appropriate action. I certainly intend to do so on this most serious matter. It is interesting to me to note that this situation has emerged only because of the way the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee has dramatised the clear diversion of public funds which are supposed to be going towards helping the long term unemployed, into such things as the buying of assets for fringe trendy groups, ending up in the possession and ownership of those organisations.

The average cost on a per week, per person basis of employing some of these long term unemployed on many of the projects I have looked at as a member of the Waste Watch Committee is up around the $650 a week mark. A very small proportion of that money is going to pay the wages of the long term unemployed. Where is the rest of the money going? Even the average figure taken over the whole of this $1.4 billion program-I must say that we can work out the average so far only on the report for the last financial year which was tabled in the Senate-of employing someone in the CEP is $510 per week, a figure far higher than the average wage that the long term unemployed would have received. An unacceptably large proportion of this money is being diverted into other areas. We want to know what they are. We want to know what these assets are that are being bought for these crazy fringe groups. One such group, as I understand it, is an adjunct of the Italian Communist Party. Others are fronts for the Socialist Workers Party.

If the Government really wants to give away goodies to these groups, let it do so honestly. Let it not hide behind the CEP which it is using as a device, purportedly helping unemployed people to obtain temporary jobs. When the temporary jobs end, the assets involved go to the sponsoring organisations, which I might say have an appalling ring about them when one looks at the long list of them. However, one is not allowed to look at the long list. First one gets blocked in this place. One gets blocked if one rings the Department. One gets blocked at the Minister's office. If one wants to make an FOI application one has to pay for it. The last little bill that Mr Brown was threatened with by the Minister for Finance was for $400 for daring to try to find out information that should be readily available to him.

Let us see why this issue has suddenly blown up. It is self-evident. The examinations of the Waste Watch Committee found that there has been clear evidence of inadequate investigation and supervision of CEP submissions. Failure to proceed with approved projects and the diversion of money into alternative projects after the approved projects turned out to be impractical have emerged following the release of our report. Senator Walsh in this place today attempted to make great political capital out of the fact that one of these projects that I said had not gone ahead, had gone ahead. He was wrong in a sense on both occasions. The reason, and what actually happened, are very different from what the Minister was endeavouring to suggest to the Senate.

I said that the money provided to the Wollongong Workers Information Research Centre to organise the first national depressed regions conference had not been spent on such a conference. I said that the conference had not taken place. Senator Walsh said that yes, it had and that I was clearly wrong and that the conference had been held on the 16 and 17 March. At the time I held up a speech given by a gentleman called Mr Tom Uren, MP, Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. The speech was given at a conference, certainly in Wollongong and certainly in March-17 March 1985. The conference was called `A Conference on Australian Industry-the Future'. That is what the conference was about. Let me read from a brochure which explained what the conference was to be about. It was to be about `Industry policy and the accord, regional development and labour movement strategy'. Not one mention of national depressed regions appeared in the conference's publicity brochure. Clearly, the money allocated under the CEP was diverted into a vastly different conference under the apparent control of the left wing South Coast Labour Council.

The conference entitled `A Conference on Australian Industry-the Future' was jointly run by the South Coast Labour Council, the Australian Political Economy Movement, which is a left wing body, the Centre for Multicultural Studies and the Wollongong Workers Information and Research Centre. The keynote speaker was Mr Tom Uren. There is no doubt that this conference was a left wing political talkfest, bearing little relation to the so-called first national depressed regions conference for which the Government has allocated over $500 per week per unemployed person for 39 weeks to arrange.

Inquiries made today at the Whyalla and Newcastle councils-we thought they were relevant seeing that they could be described as other depressed regions-reveal no record of any invitation to attend any gathering or conference in Wollongong purporting to relate to depressed regions. In view of the nature of the conference that was ultimately held, the Government now surely has an obligation to advise the public of what happened to the difference between the amount paid in wages each week to the five long term unemployed people and the total weekly grant that works out at more than $500 per person per week. Presumably, these long term unemployed were paid nothing like $500 each per week. Where did the rest of the money go? Why will the Government not come clean? What is the cover-up for? Why can we not have the information? Why are we going to be charged if we ask for information under the Freedom of Information Act which this Government has a duty and obligation to give us, particularly after a Minister gets up in this chamber and deliberately seeks to mislead the chamber on such an issue?

The Minister then went on to talk about another matter. He said that the clowns episode had not proceeded. This was an issue that I raised in the Waste Watch Committee report which talked about a proposal in which training was to be given to four long term unemployed people as clowns in Canberra at a cost to the Government of $440 each per week. I said this seemed to be curious when it was related to the amount of money that is the maximum payable to a student learning to be an engineer, trying to learn a skill or doing a university or tertiary course. The maximum is $78 a week, but not under this scheme. It was to have cost the Government $440 a week.

I must say that the Minister was part right in saying that it did not go ahead because he has a point to a degree. What happened was a triumph of government incompetence over government waste. This funding was announced by the Minister in a Press release on 6 December 1985 but the Arts Council of the ACT, as sponsor, was not advised that funding was available until four weeks ago-that is, about 10 weeks after the Press release from the Minister's office-and so it was far too late for the project to proceed. It is clearly one of those cases where the Government's incompetence saved it from wasting money. The Minister then proceeded to say; `Yes, but one clown development did go ahead and that was under the previous Government's wage pause money'.

I remind the Minister that, unfortunately, a most regrettable event took place early in March 1983-not only did the then Government lose an election but also I lost my seat, making it doubly regrettable. From then on the administration of such programs, which were only in a very preliminary stage, I might say, from when they were announced back in November 1982, was the responsibility of the Hawke Labor Government and the recommendation for that program came from the Cain Labor Government in Victoria. The Cain Labor Government got clobbered in the media, quite properly so, and clobbered in the Victorian Parliament for this incredible operation in Gippsland called the La Trobe Valley Arts Collective which, according to the Melbourne Age, involved people learning to be, as the expression was, lesbian clowns.

I do not know the rights or wrongs of this. All I know is that the Minister had an incredible hide to try to pretend that this was the responsibility of the previous Government. The Minister is no doubt clearly embarrassed by the fact that his colleague Mr Cain went ahead with a project which was nonsense and for which he got properly criticised. But to pretend at Question Time, as he did today, that somehow this was a sin of the previous Government, was totally deceptive.

Even worse were comments made by one of his colleagues, Mr Hollis, the honourable member for Throsby in the other House, about another matter. He claimed that the Wollongong women's centre has been badly dealt with by my committee and that the facts were wrong. He says that it did not use its CEP funding to buy a van. If so, this raises very serious questions of where the money went.

Let us look at the mathematics. The centre was granted $82,187 for three jobs for 52 weeks at an average cost to the Government of $525 per job per week. However, the wages paid to the three long term unemployed people would have been as much as $200 a week less than this. If the difference-$200 a week per person for 52 weeks-did not go into buying the van, where did it go? Will the Government come clean and tell us? There seems to be multi-millions of dollars missing somehow. It did not get paid to the unemployed. In the Wollongong case we are assured by the honourable member for Throsby that it did not go to buying a van because that was bought under the wage pause program, once again administered by the Hawke Government. That means the centre got a van, which is a capital item, instead of spending that money on wages for unemployed people. That has happened.

I am interested in finding out, if that $82,000, which looks to me to be at least $30,000 more than the cost of employing people over that period should have been, did not go to buying a van, where it went. Mr Hollis says that all the centre bought in equipment was an old typewriter, but $30,000 is an awful lot of pay for an old typewriter. If the centre did not get the money, why does the Government keep putting out Press releases saying all these wonderful things it has done if it has not got the honesty and decency to come out and say `Sorry, we have withdrawn some of that money' or `Sorry, it did not go ahead'.

In relation to the clowns in Canberra, the people would not know that the Government in fact reneged on a deal or did not go ahead with a deal. The unemployed of Canberra would still think the Government has done a great thing and given $30,000 or so. The people would not know that had not happened if the Opposition had not raised it in the first place. In Wollongong the people would not know what had happened to the $30,000 or so if the Opposition had not raised it. How many more instances are there in this $1.4 billion program where we do not know what has happened to the money and we do not know whether programs have gone ahead? The Government does not want to tell us. The Government is putting up increasing barriers so that we do not find out. It is now determined to charge members of the Opposition for the cost of freedom of information applications. What has this Government got to hide? Why will it not come clean and why do we have to put up with the deceptive nonsense that came from the Minister for Finance this morning?

There is no doubt that the evidence today of how the Government is responding to the Waste Watch Committee's reports clearly indicates that this Government has something to hide, clearly indicates that this Government is embarrassed and clearly indicates that this Government is running for cover. I promise this Government that it will have a lot more to worry about in the future from the reports of the Waste Watch Committee.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to articles in the Press about the provision of smallwares-that is cutlery, crockery and similar items-for the new Parliament House. The procurement of smallwares will be the direct responsibility of the Parliament and not the Parliament House Construction Authority.

INTERJECT.PARA: The matter has been considered by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House over a number of meetings commencing in mid-1985. At its meeting on 21 February 1986 the Committee agreed in principle to the purchase of new items rather than the supplementation of existing crockery, flatware and hollow-ware. The Committee further agreed: That the designs be commercial; that tenders, which are to include the proposed designs, be called from within Australia and overseas and that they be called separately for crockery and flatware and hollow-ware; that present holdings of flat- ware, crockery and hollow-ware be subsequently sold to effect some cost offsetting; and that specifications for the tenders be prepared for subsequent consideration by the Joint Standing Committee.

Honourable senators will note that the Committee has decided that an open tendering system conforming to government purchasing policy will be used. The Department of Local Government and Administrative Services is providing advice on appropriate tender processes and is assisting in developing a program and the necessary specifications. The effect of this decision is that no commitment has been given to any particular designer or manufacturer. Final decisions on the specification have yet to be made by the Joint Standing Committee.

Some Press articles have referred to costs of the smallwares. Under the proposals determined by the Joint Standing Committee costs have been assessed at $2.7m and funding to this extent has been sought by the Joint House Department in the 1986-87 financial year. Other costs associated with fitting out kitchen and dining areas are included within the general project budget for the New Parliament House and are funded through the Parliament House Construction Authority.
